title: how queen celebrated ve day
story: colourised" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailGazing down along The Mall, all they could see was a tide of humanity ebbing and flowing in waves of euphoria. The two young princesses, Elizabeth and Margaret Rose, had known for some time that this moment was coming and that victory in Europe was assured. But, as they joined the King and Queen on the balcony of Buckingham Palace on VE Day in , the sheltered young royals were unprepared for the electric atmosphere and sense of release bubbling from the crowds. They were desperate to be part of it. A few hours later, Lilibet, , and her -year-old sister sneaked out of the palace with the blessing of their parents, who agreed “the poor darlings” deserved a little fun at last. Then, going almost unrecognised, they found themselves dancing with strangers, joining a rowdy conga and cheering up at their waving parents as they appeared again on the balcony. “I think it was one of the most memorable moments of my le,” the Queen would recall in a rare and candid TV interview in . “I remember lines of unknown people linking arms and walking down Whitehall, all of us just swept along on a tide of happiness and relief.” The Queen will share her memories in a VE Day th anniversary address at pm today – the same time her father spoke to the nation in .  Earlier in the day, Prince Charles will read extracts from his grandfather George VI’s diary. King George VI and Queen Elizabeth had steadfastly refused to leave London during the war, despite an extremely near miss when the Luftwaffe pulverised the Buckingham Palace Chapel in September . The princesses remained at Windsor Castle and their parents joined them a few days before, knowing victory was imminent. The King had been working on his victory address with voice coach Lionel Logue, who had helped him overcome his stammerOn Monday, May , the royals ed to Buckingham Palace as it was announced that Tuesday and Wednesday would be VE Day public holidays.  Huge crowds began descending on London overnight, awaiting Prime Minister Winston Churchill’s announcement the following afternoon. The King wrote in his diary: “The day we have been longing for has arrived at last and we can look back with thankfulness to God that our tribulation is over.” Loudspeakers and floodlights were being erected in The Mall and the palace balcony – newly strengthened after the bombings – was decorated with crimson and gold drapes. Princess Elizabeth, a mechanic and driver in the Auxiliary Territorial Service, dressed in her unorm while Princess Margaret wore a light-coloured jacket and skirt. Then, after a morning of tense anticipation, the royals listened to Mr Churchill’s pm speech from Downing Street.  They could hear the crowds going wild outside as Churchill ended with the words: “Advance Britannia! Long live the cause of freedom! God Save the King!” And then they made the first of many balcony appearances that day, including one with Churchill himself. Lionel Logue and his we, Myrtle, arrived at the palace to dine with the royals before Logue gave the King’s speech a final run-through. By now the princesses were pleading with their parents to be allowed to join the party. Finally, they agreed to let them leave in a group of , including some guards officers, the Queen’s cousin, the Hon Margaret Rhodes, and lady-in-waiting Jean Woodroffe. They were also joined by Lord “Porchy” Porchester, who later become the Queen’s racing manager, and Peter Townsend, the king’s equerry who sparked a national crisis a decade later when, though a orced man, he won Princess Margaret’s heart.  Speaking in , Margaret Rhodes revealed: “We crossed the forecourt at Buckingham Palace and got to the railings and there were these masses and masses of people. There was a general thing of, ‘We want the King and Queen!’ which we all frantically joined in with. “We were amazed when, five or  minutes later, the windows opened and they came out on to the balcony. “It was like a wonderful escape for the girls. I don’t think they’d ever been out among millions of people.” In  the Queen herself revealed: “We were terried of being recognised, so I pulled my unorm cap well down over my eyes. “But a Grenadier officer among our party... said he refused to be seen in the company of another officer improperly dressed – so I had to put my cap on normally.” The Queen was recognised by at least one eagle-eyed member of the crowd though – a teenage lad who stole a dance.  Ronald Thomas’s story only emerged in  when the partially fictionalised movie A Royal Night Out featured a similar incident Ronald, then , from Harrow, had travelled to London with a pal. In Trafalgar Square, he recognised Elizabeth. His grandson Thomas, , explained: “They danced together for a few minutes – just a merry dance. “She denied her identity at first but he was so sure, he said, ‘I’d recognise your face anywhere!’ “Eventually she admitted it but told him to keep it quiet. “He felt a strong sense of civic duty to the future monarch, which is why he didn’t expose her then, and why he has been very bashful about it since. “There were several big blokes with her, chaperoning, and after a few minutes they all moved on.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A brave schoolboy who spent five months in hospital after suffering from meningitis has ed home after having his arms and legs amputated.Luke Mortimer, seven, from Skipton in West Yorkshire, had been in Sheffield Childrenaposs Hospital since before Christmas. The rugby-mad youngster has undergone  operations, including the amputation of his legs and hands. Now his family, which includes dad Adam, mum Christine, and older brother Harry, , have welcomed Luke back to their home. He will now undergo physiotherapy to help him to stand and walk again and it is hoped that he will eventually have prosthetic limbs fitted.  Luke fell ill on December  last year and was diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis, the most dangerous strain of the disease.It has a fatality rate of up to  per cent and can often lead to sepsis.Survivors may suffer lasting long-term effects and many have to have limbs amputated due to gangrene caused by blood poisoning. He was initially taken to Airedale Hospital but was transferred to Sheffield by the Embrace team, a mobile ambulance unit who transport seriously ill children across Yorkshire.  Luke was placed in an induced coma and was dependent on a ventilator and dialysis machine. Family, friends and their colleagues at Skipton RUFC - where Luke played - have collected more than £, for the Mortimer family through fundraising efforts. The money will enable them to adapt their home for Lukeaposs disabilities and buy specialist medical equipment. It will also cover living expenses as Adam, a self-employed builder, has been unable to work while caring for Luke.

Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailToday marks the th anniversary of Britainaposs Victory in Europe, marking the start of the end of World War Two. The country took to the streets to celebrate the end of years of fighting, bombings and death. Those who were there share their special memories of VE Day. Marion Parry, , of Aberdare, Wales Marion lived with her parents, Ethel and Ernest. Her dad joined up as a gunnery soldier with a Royal Artillery anti-aircraft regiment defending naval bases in Scotland, near the Orkney Islands. This family photo was taken when he ed to Wales, in June , to meet baby Marion. Marion, far right, honours May ,  in verse... A bonfire stands upon the hill for everyone to see, The daily news reads, “Peace at last! We’ve won the victory.” Flags are flying, people singing, children start to shout. But I am only four years old, I don’t know what it’s all about. Soldiers in their khaki suits, relief spread on their faces. Shake hands, join arms with “ GI Joes” of many dferent races. “We’re going home at last!” shouts Bill. “New York, here I come!” “Oh! What will we do now ” moans Dai. “Who’ll give us chewing gum ” My Mickey Mouse gas mask will finally be put away, In the hope that it may never again see the light of day. The air raid shelters will soon come down, As peace s to our small town. The village band plays a Glenn Miller tune to set feet tapping with a swing. And pit hooters sound throughout the hills, while church bells start to ring. A radio plays Vera Lynn, as she begins to croon, “There’ll be bluebirds over the white clfs of Dover,” That ever-popular tune. It’s time at last, the torch is lit and the bonfire starts to burn. Crackling wood and soaring flames light up each face in turn. A new tomorrow will soon dawn and war will fade away, But we must never forget the price that we all had to pay For freedom and the right to live in peace at last. However many years go by, we remember the past. Now,  years on, we’ll remember, and celebrate with tea. There’ll be plenty to eat and plenty to drink, more than enough for you and me. But we will still stop and wonder how we survived each day, Of rationing and coupon books and queues along the way. Yes, the time has long since passed but it seems no time ago, That I still remember VE Day, When I was only four.” Gillian Holding, , Sheffield I was nine and living on Firth Park Road on VE Day and we couldn’t have a street party as the road was too busy with trams, buses and tanks. The houses all had Union Flags outside. My family had a very tatty flag which had been used for the  celebration.  Opposite our house was a Chinese laundry and I remember the anticipation of seeing which flag they would hang out – it was the Union Jack! As there was no street party, my aunt gave us some money and coupons to help arrange a party on a green, open space nearby. We had sandwiches and cake but I was very upset that the younger children had jelly too – it would have been such a treat.My father went on the train to London and had an amazing time with everyone smiling, laughing anddancing.Pamela Broadhurst, , Dorset This is a photo taken on VE Day. I was five and my brother was eight but I still remember the day. In the evening there was a party in a marquee for the adults – but us kids stayed up anyway. All our friends and neighbours from Eric Avenue in Padgate, Warrington, were there. It was such a happy time, though growing up during the war meant I really didn’t know any other way of le. You’d hear the air raids and knew it was time to run home. It was just what we did. But the first time we could have sweets, it was amazing – the queues used to go round the block. There were few men there. My father had been in the Army from the beginning and was still away. I now live in Dorset with my husband Colin, , and we will soon celebrate our th wedding anniversary. Sheila Doughton, , Wolverhampton  I was aged six when the war started. On VE Day we had a big street party. One of the neighbours, Mr Emery, brought his piano out into the street and his we played it. All the surrounding streets had lorries driving round with the children on the back who were all dressed up. Each truck had a theme, ours was The Victory Queen. Claire, being the eldest of us, was the Victory Queen... we were all dressed in red, white and blue. The lorries were driven round the surrounding streets and through the hospital grounds. We children were so excited and we all really enjoyed the day.  We had a small shelter in our back garden at home and some nights we used it and other nights we stayed in the pantry under the stairs. Our ARP Warden, Mr Courtney, used to come down our entry during the air raids and shout at Mum through the pantry window: “Are you all all right, Mrs Bate ” In my mind I can still hear the German planes flying over us – the hum, hum, hum sound that they made. You could tell they were loaded. We used to hear the whistle bombs being dropped and us children would go out the next day to pick up the bits of shrapnel that had fallen. Thomas Spittle, , Gamesley, Derbyshire  Thomas was the first baby born in Manchester on VE Day – and his middle names, Victor and Edward, are a reminder of his special birthday. Here, he reveals what sharing such a famous date means to him... I am extremely proud of being born on VE Day. My mum, Margaret, told me she went into labour the day before, when everyone was preparing for a party outside the house. I was born one or two minutes after midnight on the day itself, I just made it! I weighed lb oz. I was so big the nurse said Hitler must have known I was coming! Mum held me in her arms as she watched the bonfires and the dancing in the streets with my older sisters.  We lived on Wendover Road, in Urmston, Greater Manchester. My parents had a five-bedroom house with a big cellar where they used to go when the sirens went.I remember bunk beds there when I was growing up. My dad Jack worked as an ambulance driver in Kent during the war but he made it back up for my birth.My mum and sisters said he’d bring up boxes of fruit for them. They used to share them around kids on our street. I now have six grandchildren and three great-grandchildren and I’ve talked to them about the meaning of my name. It’s important not to forget. VE Day meant a lot to a lot of people. The war should never have happened, it caused a lot of hardship all over the world but at least we won. Five years ago we had bunting and flags out, and all the family here to celebrate the th anniversary of VE Day as well as my birthday.This year I’ll be  but the celebrations will be more muted as we are facing a dferent battle today. Val Nuttall, , Stockport, Cheshire  My mother, Hannah Kathleen Davies, was in the Auxiliary Territorial Service as a PT instructor when war broke out. My father, Thomas George Beaumont, was a Lieutenant in an artillery regiment. They met when they were stationed together at a camp near Derby before he was posted abroad. I was born on VE Day. At the time, my mother was living with his family at the corner shop they owned. When Mum went into labour, Dad’s sister was sent to the phone box to ring for a taxi to take her to the nursing home where she was to give birth. My aunt had been looking forward to going to celebrate victory but spent the day and night running between the shop and phone box, checking the progress of the labour, relating it to Grandma. Luckily, she didn’t hold it against me that she missed out on the fun and became my godmother. The s and s brought challenges of growing up but I was lucky to be born when resilience and optimism were a huge part of the national character. This is a photo of myself and my parents, in about June . Dad’s still in unorm, my mother looks gorgeous... and I was too young to spoil it! Joy Lennick, , who now lives in Alicante, Spain  Joy wrote a memoir called My Gentle War about being an evacuee. The eldest of three kids, her dad was in the RAF. She recalls: “When peace was finally declared, Dad was still serving, Mum was working as a welder and we children were evacuated to our third place. I had another brother, named Royce, as Dad was stationed nearer to home. “We were overjoyed to be reunited as a whole family, while mourning the loss of Dad’s youngest brother Bernard.  “I can recall the feeling of euphoria which swept the country when the war ended. “Our parents took us on the train to London. There were bonfires, like beacons of hope, blazing in back gardens and flags waving everywhere.We watched, entranced, a huge firework display from Westminster Bridge, and giggled as sailors climbed lampposts and kissed as many girls as they could catch! “Goodness knows what time we arrived home, tired but so happy.” Joyce Hughes, , Hale, Liverpool  During the war I lived in a terraced house in Vale Road, Woolton, with my parents Teresa and Jack Langley, and six brothers and sisters. Dad and Mum worked in a components factory. I remember sirens and air raids. We used to go to a family with a shelter or to one in Gladstone Street. We were only children, so it seemed like a big adventure. We were still going to school but had to carry little gas masks with us. Once, in  when I was , we came out and a bomb had dropped on the next street. It only demolished one house but when we went back to ours, Dad went to put the key in the front door and it just fell backwards into the house.The windows had gone. There was soot everywhere but our little dog lived through it. On the day the war ended there was a big bonfire at the bottom of the road, someone had pushed a piano out and everyone was singing and dancing. A few days later we had a street party in the afternoon. I have no idea where the food came from but there was plenty to go around. Rex Wellard, , Chigwell, Essex  Rex was evacuated to three dferent places in six years and has written a book called Don’t Forget Your Gasmask about his experiences. He says: “I had been home with my family for about five weeks when at daybreak one Monday, we were woken up by a cacophony of noise coming from the river.The boats moored on the Thames were sounding their steam horns and many gave hoots emulating the Vin Morse code. ‘That’s it!’ my dad said. ‘The war’s over.’ “My friend and I caught a train to London and squeezed down The Mall to join thousands in front of Buckingham Palace.The crowd were chanting for the Royal Family, who came on to the balcony with Churchill. The loud cheering and flag-waving was years of tension being released. “In Shaftesbury Avenue, an American Forces club had its windows open wide and a gramophone blared out music. Soldiers leaned out calling to girls as a long conga line snaked about. “They threw fire-crackers down, too. A middle-aged couple got a shock when one went down the man’s sweater and exploded, blowing a hole in it. He was unharmed but his we was most annoyed.” Bill Bennett, , of Kidderminster  He joined the Merchant Navy at  but was seconded to the Royal Navy. He worked on Plutoto allow petrol to be pumped from the UK to France and was mentioned in Dispatches for his bravery for helping a wounded colleague. There were a lot of shells and e-bombers and I wasn’t allowed to carry a gun as I was from the Merchant Navy. But I was too busy getting on with the job to be scared. I just remember tremendous noise, as well as hundreds of planes, and the smell of cordite. We sailed back to Folkestone on May  but got back into the harbour late so stayed aboard the ship. Next morning as I went on deck, there was a buzz of excitement. A group of men on the quay were talking and looking at a paper. I shouted “What’s happening ” They said the war was over in Europe and the Germans had surrendered. Looking around you could see people shouting and talking to one another and the excitement and buzz was unbelievable. After five years of tension, there was such relief for all. The next two days were spent celebrating on land. We felt a great lt. But our war was far from over.Bill, a Royal British Legion member, was involved in the Japanese campaigns and was finally demobbed in November .Don Sheppard, , Royal Engineers and stDivision  My ision was involved in the last big battle on May , , in Bremervorde, north-west Germany – known as the final surrender.As the attack was progressing, many of the enemy surrendered to our troops, which was the beginningof the final capitulation of all of Germany’s armed forces on VE Day. My thoughts at the time, after surviving five years of war, was relief that nobody was shooting at us any more. I’m sure the German soldiers felt the same.  Then, of course, I celebrated the event with a tipple or two. But I found myself thinking, what a futile way of le, killing one another.There was a sadness of all those comrades who would never be going home, like I was longing to do. The casualty figures from my ision alone from D-Day to VE Day was , killed, wounded and missing. Let us remember with thanksgiving and honour all those who gave their lives in the pursuit of freedom. Sergeant Fred Foster, who died in  aged , by his son Steve Foster, , author of The Soldier Who Came Back  Dad joined the Army in May  and saw action in Norway in .Over five days of fighting in deep snow in the village of Tretten, the British were subjected to continuous mortar and machine-gun fire which they had no answer to. Armed only with rles, they were eventually overrun as tanks passed through them.Hand-to-hand fighting took place in order to hold the village but it was finally taken when most of the brigade were killed, wounded or captured. Fred was imprisoned in Stalag XXA, Thorn, Poland, where in , he and a friend undertook an escape to the Swiss border. At the border they were recaptured, harshly interrogated and eventually ed to the camp. From there, Fred was moved to Stalag  in Hohenfels, Baia, where he was finally liberated by American forces on May , . However, there were , allied PoWs released in Germany in May  and most would not get home by VE Day. The pure logistics of feeding, clothing and transporting them was a huge challenge. Documents show that Fred was given a day pass from his camp on May , so he was effectively still a prisoner but held by British authorities and he did not get home until May . He and his friends, who had spent more than five years as prisoners, were still in PoW camps in Germany on VE day and not out on the streets in their home towns celebrating. This is perhaps a little-known fact. Walter Taylor, , of Waterlooville, Hants, served as a private with the Tank Corps from . A D-Day veteran, he was awarded the Legion d’Honneur in   He says: “I volunteered at  because I hated my job in a Lancashire shoe factory. On D-Day we landed on Gold Beach and I saw some terrible sights. That night one of our drivers was sleeping under his tank when the Luftwaffe hit it. “He was the first of our casualties but not the last. I lost some great colleagues as we made our way through Europe, including Geordie, who looked after me like a second father. “We pushed on to the Rhine and I started to get the feeling we might be getting to the end – youthful optimism, perhaps. “Then, in May , we were in a wood near Luneburg Heath in Germany. There were lots of vehicles moving around – and I now know that was because the Germans were surrendering. At about midday on the th, our Sergeant Major came out and said: ‘That’s it, it’s all over.’  “We were told it was VE Day and were very pleased, obviously. But we didn’t have any booze to celebrate with so I just had a cup of tea. One of my mates was fed up and made a sign saying ‘VE Day and NO BEER’ and hung it on a tank. “So I’ve promised myself I am going to have a bottle of beer on Friday to mark this th anniversary. I’m going to toast all the lads who never came home.“ Walter was demobbed in , ing to join the police force. He married Vera and the couple had three children. He adds: “Before the coronavirus lockdown I was meant to be coming to London to lay a wreath on the Cenotaph. “But I’m hoping I’ll be able to do that on Remembrance Sunday in November instead.” Barbara Hurman, , from Aylesbury, Bucks, joined the Army at  and became a teleprinter operator in the Royal Corps of Signals  Following D-Day I volunteered to go abroad and joined the Central Mediterranean Forces. I was in southern Italy when news of the end of the war came but I never had a chance to celebrate. My unit was in transit, waiting to be posted to our next billet, so we weren’t allowed out. It was only afterwards I realised I had spent VE Day confined to barracks! As a member of the Royal British Legion, I was looking forward to taking part in the VE Day events in London this year. But now I will be celebrating at home as I didn’t get the opportunity to all those years ago. You don’t tend to hear so much about the work that women did to help win the Second World War. Women played a valuable role – at home and abroad – and that should be acknowledged more. Bernard Morgan, , from Crewe, Cheshire, was a codebreaker who found out about the German surrender via a telex two days earlier than most. He still has the original message  I landed on Gold Beach at .pm on D-Day – the youngest RAF sergeant to land in Normandy.I can still vividly remember seeing dead bodies scattered all over the beach as I came ashore, and that is a sight that will stay with me for ever. By May, , I was stationed in Schneverdingen in Germany – where I got advance warning that VE Day was coming. I got a telex to let me know that the war was ending and that the German surrender was imminent. I still feel very privileged.  I remember VE Day very well, the drinks just appeared from nowhere and we lit a bonfire, and had a massive party. It’s so important that we make the most of these opportunities to remember what happened – not just to celebrate the achievement but also to ensure that such horrors never happen again. Secret agent Odette Hallowes, by her granddaughters Sophie Parker and Nicole Miller-Hard Our French-born grandmother Odette was recruited by the British Government to join the Special Operations Executive and work undercover in occupied countries. After training, she joined SOE agent Peter Churchill in France but, in April , they were both betrayed, captured, and imprisoned. Odette was brutally tortured for information about her fellow agents but refused to say anything, saving their lives and enabling them to carry on their vital work.During her confinement in the notorious Ravensbruck bunker she did all she could to try to keep her mind and body active and retain her dignity. In the spring of , as the Allies were closing in, Odette, emaciated and extremely ill, was taken from Ravensbruck by the prison commandant, who had been instrumental in the extermination of , women.They went in his own car and she was told, ominously, that it would not be necessary to bring her things. She was sure her end had come and he would drag her into the woods and shoot her.  But it was not to be. On May , just days from the German surrender, the prison commandant handed her over to the American military base and her relief must have been immeasurable. We are sure that arriving home in England after two years of incarceration and knowing she was at last going to be reunited with her daughters must have been monumental for Odette. The sight of London’s streets hung with the glorious flags of military victory, and the joyous sounds of the VE celebrations would have affirmed that her hopes and dreams had finally become a reality. Odette was awarded the George Cross, an MBE and the Legion D’Honneur. Alec Borrie, , Slade Green, Kent  I was the youngest member of the st SAS and was with them for two years during the war. On VE Day I was in a transit camp in Chesterfield and the news came at about midday. I can sum up VE Day in two words: Getting drunk.  We went to a pub and I spent quite some time trying to strike up a conversation with another man from st SAS, until I realised I was actually looking at myself in a large mirror. Eileen Storey, , Norfolk  Every time I hear the lovely Vera Lynn sing The White Clfs of Dover, I am transported back to the day when I joined the Auxiliary Territorial Service at the age of . I became a very proud gunner.  We were positioned on the white clfs of Dover at the time when the V and V rockets, doodlebugs, were beginning to attack. Most of the crews were young girls. I still have lovely memories of friendships formed during the war. John Stuart Chapman, by daughter Jan Stewart, , London  My father was an Able Seaman in the Royal Navy and turned  on VE Day. His ship sailed into Plymouth harbour as the church bells were ringing out for the end of the war. But to him, it felt like everyone could have been celebrating his st. Dad, who had done some bell ringing, found a nearby church and rang a peal of bells himself. Dad, who was only  when he was called up, operated depth charges on destroyers. He didn’t really talk about the horrors he must have seen but he told us two stories. He thought he had been blinded when a depth charge exploded near him – but found he could see when his eyelashes, which had been stuck together, were trimmed. And one night in the Atlantic, a huge wave washed him overboard, but the next wave washed him back on, which he said was a miracle. Dad, who worked for BT after the war, died at  in . Lillian Cox and Doris Hobday , of Tipton, West Mids, are the oldest identical twins in the UK  The end of the war was announced on the radio, which our parents rented because we had hardly any money. At first we were so relieved but everyone was worried in case it started again or another war broke out. We lived in the Black Country, and worked in a factory. Even during the war we went to work each day, carrying our gas masks and ID cards. Everything was rationed.We had coupons for food, clothes, furniture. Times were hard but we got through it. When we came home from work we would hear the sirens and had to go straight to the shelter in our garden.  We used to sit there frightened while we heard the loud planes overhead. Our father was a firefighter looking after the streets to make sure everyone was safe. Doris had recently got married and her husband, Ray, was called up – he was a private in the Army and away for two years and eight months. When he went away he had a full head of hair. He came back bald and it never grew back. Towards the end of the war, a bomb went off just behind where we lived. It shook all the houses. Our mam was shouting: “Arrrrh, my bloody mantle is broken!” But we later learned that bomb killed three children and a doctor. When we heard the war had finally ended we were able to relax a little and start living our lives. Joyce Masters, by her daughter Marion Trathen, , from Cornwall  My mother wrote her story down before she died in , aged . She joined the land army in , aged , and was sent from London to Cornwall.On VE Day, she was cutting cabbages to be sent on the train at midday, when the housekeeper called: “The war is over!”Needless to say, the cabbages were thrown into the air and they had a cabbage fight. They danced and sang “the cabbages never saw the railway truck”. Marie Scott, , New Malden, Surrey I was in Fort Southwick on D-Day and transmitted messages to and from the beaches. I went to London for VE Day with my friend Betty, aiming to walk down the Mall to Buckingham Palace. But most of London was determined to do the same thing. We met a human tide and were hugged and kissed by soldiers, sailors and airmen! People were delirious with joy. Marie is supported by The Taxi Charity for Military Veterans, taxicharity.orgEdith Pleasance, , from Wymondham, Norfolk, was on a delayed honeymoon For most of the war I worked in a factory making aircraft parts. One day a voice announced “Mrs Pleasance, please report to the main gate”. A friend was waiting for me with a telegram. My husband Jim had been captured by the Germans  months earlier at Anzio and incarcerated in a Stalag in Eastern Germany, so I was pretty certain he would have been on the much-publicised Death March.  I tore open the envelope and didn’t know whether to laugh or cry as I read: “ARRIVED SAFELY. SEE YOU SOON. JIM.” Jim and I had married on his first leave in  but we had no honeymoon. So after he arrived home – at am on April ,  – we decided to go to Plymouth. We were there on VE Day when we heard Churchill on the tannoy. Then it was announced that celebrations for all would be organised on Plymouth Hoe. The party was like six New Year’s Eves rolled into one. Si Liberman was a -year-old US airman stationed at Attlebridge airfield, near Norwich  The explosion of joy had not yet erupted. But there, in the heart of London, darkness was strangely absent on one city street.A stream of light illuminated almost an entire city block. Some happy soul had raised a blackout shade.And for the first time in nearly six years, it was done without fear of inviting an air raid warden’s citation or German bombs. That marvellous lighted scene, foretelling the end of Europe’s deadliest period, has stayed with me all these years. The date was May , . I was  then and a B- bomber radio gunner on a three-day pass from my air base outside Norwich, a five-hour train ride away.On an Underground train en route to Piccadilly Circus, I kind of got the picture after spotting a newspaper headline. “Unconditional Surrender Imminent,” it screamed. By pm the next day, it was official.  Standing on the War Ministry balcony above Whitehall at that hour, a beaming Winston Churchill flashed his usual V sign. This time, though, his V for victory was no symbolic promise. Hostilities with Nazi Germany were over. “This is your victory,” he told a huge crowd that had gathered. Cheers grew into one helluva party. People poured into the streets, shouting, dancing, embracing. They mounted double-decker buses and utility poles, waved flags, started bonfires and danced the hokey pokey around a statue of Queen Victoria. Sirens blared, car horns honked and church bells pealed. I found myself drawn to Buckingham Palace. A roar from the crowd and wild applause greeted the appearance of people on the balcony.  From where I stood among a mass of humanity, King George VI and Queen Elizabeth, their princess daughters, Elizabeth and Margaret, and Prime Minister Churchill were a distant blur. That night floodlights illuminated Buckingham Palace and the Houses of Parliament for the first time since the Battle of Britain began in . And Big Ben’s toll, signalling the official end of the war in Europe, was greeted by exploding fireworks and screaming sirens. The celebration went on for two days. Thomas Byrnes Barry was a technical sergeant, aged , at Headquarters Squadron, th Air Depot Group of the US Air Force Army  His daughter, Patricia Coleman, shares a letter he wrote to his we while in London We arrived in Parliament Square about .pm on VE Day. The place was overflowing with people – civilians and members of the Armed Forces: British, American, French, Poles, Norwegians, Belgians.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA Ryanair plane was forced to make an emergency landing after a mum-to-be went into labour at  weeks. Lauren McLean, , was flying back from a Tenere to Birmingham when an hour into the flight she felt like she needed to push. An announcement asking for help was answered by a complete stranger - midwe Angela Chamberlain who was also ing home from her holiday. She became Laurenaposs saviour, helping her avoid giving birth until the flight was erted to Faro in Portugal and she would have access to a hospital, reports Birmingham Live.As Lauren lay on the floor of the plane, Angela took her weight as the craft landed to avoid adding to her discomfort. Little Oscar Jacob Wall was born only a few minutes later, weighing lb oz. But Lauren wants to warn other mums-to-be of the need for full insurance and the dangers of flying - even when, as in her case, they were medically cleared to do so.to get the Mirroraposs biggest and best stories delivered straight to your inbox at www.mirror email Lauren, from Marston Green in the Midlands, said Angela, a midwe at Walsall Manor Hospital, was her saviour. It was like a Hollywood movie, Angela said.I had to pin Lauren to the floor while trying to straddle her. An air hostess was looking out of the window so she could tell me the the exact moment we would land so we would brace ourselves and I could take the weight on my hands on the floor. You can watch Lauren talking about her experience on the above video and Angela is in a video further below. Both Angela and Lauren are big fans of BBCaposs Le and Birth series, which was recorded in Birmingham. The fourth episode at pm on Tuesday May  will feature posthumous footage of Birmingham Womenaposs Hospital and Childrenaposs Hospital neonatologist Dr Vishna Rasiah whose death from coronavirus was announced on April .  How the drama unfolded Trying hard not to give birth at , feet was the last thing administrator Lauren expected when she boarded aflight from Tenere to head back to Birmingham. Within five minutes of the jet landing in Portugal, she was in an emergency ambulance. And ten minutes later Oscar was born. The boy had only been in the country for  minutes but now qualies for a Portuguese passport. Proud dad Jake is hoping itaposs a sign Oscar could be the next Ronaldo. But because Oscar had to spend the first six weeks of his le in Faro Hospital on the Algarve, Lauren said she had a more serious agenda.  The holiday plan Laurenaposs end-of-winter holiday had been booked as a Christmas present when nobody had heard of Covid-. The dates were from February  to March . Having had medical clearance first - and knowing a friend had once flown back from Australia  weeks into her pregnancy - sheaposd never considered herself to be at risk from four-hour flights to and from the Canaries. But, having taken mother Adie on holiday to Tenere with sister Jordan and their respective partners, Lauren later began to feel unwell. A doctor in Tenere thought she had a urine infection and prescribed antibiotics. With ten weeks left before her due date, Lauren was looking forward to flying home and being back in her own bed. Angela was on the same flight home with husband Russ - having booked a late winter break for the two of them at short notice. She had never met Lauren before.  The need for tests As the end of her own holiday drew near, Lauren began to realise something wasnapost quite right. Iaposd had no contractions and no waters breaking, she recalled. I just had bad pains in my lower back, hips and thighs on Wednesday. We saw a doctor before our flight who confirmed a water infection and said we would be safe to fly on Thursday. I just wanted to get home and check it out there. The flight back Once on board, Lauren said she needed to start going to the loo regularly. An hour after take off I turned to my mum and said: aposI need to push!apos You just donapost realise how much pressure there is inside a plane. Ryanair staff put out a call for anyone with medical training and Laurenaposs sister Jordan overheard some passengers thinking there was a Covid- patient on board. There was a midwe on the flight and Lauren was adamant she saved her sonaposs le. I owe everything to Angela, she said. She was our saviour. Angela could feel the babyaposs head and said I was fully dilated. Angela told me I would not be having this child on the plane I needed to wait until the hospital, with him being ten weeks early. I was having no pain relief but Angela taught me how to breathe through the contractions.  Trying not to give birth Angela - who knows some of the midwives featuring in the hit BBC series Le and Birth filmed last summer at three city hospitals - didnapost respond to the medical call at first as she thought she might not be qualied. But when it became apparent there was no doctor on board, Angela told cabin crew she was a midwe and met Lauren in the toilet at the front of the plane. With all of the other passengers looking in their direction, Angela moved Lauren to the back of the plane and two doors were opened from the rear loos to provide a degree of screening privacy. She encouraged Lauren to lie down to try to tilt her pelvis backwards so gravity might help to keep the baby in. Lauren was then able to put one leg up on a chair normally used by cabin crew while mother Adie held her other leg up. Meanwhile, the plane was being erted to Faro. I was so trying not to give birth, said Lauren. The next half-hour was a blur of me breathing my le away and screaming that I needed to push, while breaking Jake and mumaposs hands. The midweaposs view Angela had to think counter-intuitively to try to stop Lauren from giving birth. I knew thatthe baby was born in the air at  weeks that would dangerous for the baby and possibly Lauren, too, she said. With no oxygen and not being able guarantee keeping him warm, he might not have been able to breathe on his own for long. I encouraged Lauren not to push. A mother-of-three, including two stepsons and a -year-old boy of her own, Angela has been a qualied midwe since  after previously managing a care home. Because she had booked a short-notice flight with Russ for an end-of-winter break alone in Tenere, the couple werenapost even sitting next to each other when Laurenaposs drama began. Russ didnapost even know what was happening, said Angela.  Lauren was experiencing a lot of pain and pressure and where she was sitting there was a danger the baby could have been born down the toilet. I had to spend a few minutes to get my working head on and decided to take her to the back of the plane where I asked her to lie down so I could examine her with all of the passengers facing away from us. The labour was well-established and I could see babyaposs head. But the only mask available would have been bigger than the babyaposs head and, had Lauren given birth, the only thing I might have been able to do would have been mouth-to-mouth. The stewardesses were outstanding and had two fleeces ready in case he was born. At this stage there were still three-and-a-half-hours of the flight left so they contacted the captain who found somewhere to make an emergency landing. I did the best I could do at the time and, on reflection, I donapost think I would have done anything dferently. But I do thinkLauren had had a full medical examination before leaving for the airport she would probably have been told not to fly.  The bumpy landing Having been holding Laurenaposs hands, Jake - a bricklayer - and mum Adie were told to sit down and put seat belts on. The plane made a safe, emergency landing at Faro - but at great risk to Lauren, baby and Angela since they could not be strapped in. Angela says: The plane wasnapost full because of the coronavirus, and everybody  was moved forwards so there were not as many people at the back. A stewardess told us when we were going to land. It wasnapost the best landing - I was kind of straddling Lauren and I put my hands on the floor to take the impact. Looking back, Lauren said: Within five minutes I was in an ambulance and ten minutes after that Oscar Jacob Wall arrived into our world at .pm. As soon as I got in the hospital they said I could push - and Oscar arrived after just three pushes! The journey home Being born in a foreign hospital on March  wasnapost the end of Oscaraposs debut drama. Given that he only weighed lb oz, medics wanted mum to recover and to see him grow before allowing them to fly home to Birmingham. But within days of his birth, the whole of Europe was going into Covid- lockdown. Spain and Portugal went into lockdown on March  and  respectively - before Britain followed suit on March . Even after six weeks of consistently putting on weight, doctors didnapost want Oscar to fly home with members of the public because of the Covid- risk. During Oscaraposs stay in neo-natal care in Faro Hospital, only one parent a day was allowed to visit him between am and pm due to Covid-. That was the hardest of times for us, but the nurses were incredible, said Lauren. Thankfully, Lauren was fully covered for her holiday. An air ambulance was then arranged through her travel insurance for Lauren, Jake and Oscar to fly back to Birmingham with a nurse, doctor and two pilots - leaving Adie to make her own way home via flights to Lisbon and then Stansted. Once back at Birmingham Airport on Wednesday, April , Lauren and Oscar had a five-minute ambulance ride tohome to Marston Green.

Parts of the country are set to hit C this afternoon, hotter than top tourist destinations including Monaco and Corfu. And Saturday could just shade it by reaching C and matching the highs felt on April  in Cornwall - the hottest day of , Met Office forecaster Greg Dewhurst told the .  However, stormy showers across East Anglia, southern England, south Midlands and Wales over both days could hamper the mood slightly.Regardless of the heat, many beaches and open spaces are likely to be largely empty as people stay at home due to the coronavirus lockdown.The south-east will be the warmest area today and could see C in London while Scotland will reach highs of C.  Northern Ireland will see the mercury rising to C, and northern England and Wales could each see peaks of C. Met Office forecaster Oli Claydo said: It will be a bright and warm day for most on Friday. “There will be some early morning fog in the Midlands and west of England, and scattered showers in Scotland, but that should clear by mid-morning. By the afternoon it is likely to be clear and pleasant for all, and could be pretty hot for most. “But this will start to change on Saturday as a cold front will move from Scotland, bringing scattered showers in parts. The temperature could drop as much as C by Sunday as Arctic air sweeps in from the north of the UK to bring rain and colder temperatures, with possible wintry showers in northern Scotland. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe slaughter of a generation of young men on the Western Front hung like an albatross around the necks of Britain’s war leaders during the Second World War, which was why, even before it had begun, they were determined it should never happen again. Of course, people were going to get killed but the aim was to keep the numbers to the barest minimum with a strategy known as “steel not flesh”. Britain aimed to use its vast global reach, technology, science, and ­mechanisation in an effort to limit the number of men at the coal face of war. This meant creating huge air fleets, incredible material support for ­frontline troops and developing new means of communication. Never was there to be a greater period of scientic and technological invention. Even after the fall of France and the realisation that Britain now needed to create a much bigger army, it was agreed it should be  isions in size and no more – compared with the hundreds of the Germans and Soviet Union, for example. Unlike Germany, considerable manpower was to be kept in the ­factories rather than stripping them out for the front – so much so that until the autumn of , the priority for manpower in Britain was not any of the armed services, but rather, the Ministry of Aircraft Production. Only the US would produce more aircraft in the war. Britain went on to build a staggering , by . Having seen off the invasion threat in , Britain’s prime focus was to hurriedly rebuild the Army and to secure the Atlantic. The battle across this huge ocean was rightly identied as the most important theatre of the entire conflict because, for an island nation like Britain, almost everything reached its shores through these waters, whether from the US or from India or Australia. Fortunately, the Germans had pointlessly focussed on building a surface fleet before the war, even though it could never hope to rival those of the leading maritime powers, rather than building a sizeable U-boat force. By January , only six U-boats were operating in the Atlantic and the high tonnage of ships being sunk had fallen. During the invasion scare the previous summer and autumn, convoys had been crossing the Atlantic largely without protection but now convoys of merchant ships were once again being increasingly heavily escorted by destroyers and other anti-submarine warships. The Royal Canadian navy was also rapidly growing – and manned entirely by volunteers as were all its armed services. It was a contribution that rarely gets the credit it deserves. Prioritising scientic research and development also helped win this battle. One of the key inventions was the cavity magnetron, developed in , which allowed for greater detection of smaller objects by much smaller radar antennae. Instead of having huge ft high masts, radar could now be placed on to an aircraft or ship. It was a game-changing invention and one neither the Germans nor the Japanese ever knew we had developed. At the same time, further developments were being made in improving high frequency-direction finding – known as ‘huff-duff’ – as well as developments in the global tracking of shipping and anti-submarine weaponry. In March , two of Germany’s most successful U-boat commanders, Günther Prien and Joachim Schepke, were killed and, a third, Otto Kretschmer, was captured. Because the U-boat Arm was so small, these were big losses. Then, in May, an Enigma signal coding machine was captured with its codebooks and one of Germany’s two largest battleships, the Bismarck, was sunk, forcing the Kriegsmarine’s surface fleet to skulk back to port where it largely stayed for the rest of the war. Britain still had a long way to go before the U-boat threat was destroyed but by May , it had reached a point where it was no longer going to lose the Battle of the Atlantic. That was no small achievement and by early , with aircraft now ­operating with the cavity magnetron aboard from Iceland, northern Canada and Northern Ireland, the U-boats had been pushed further into the middle of the Atlantic, which took them longer to reach and made them less effective. It was true some convoys were still being hammered, but more than % were getting through unscathed. Meanwhile, Britain’s growing army was, with the help of Commonwealth forces from Australia, India, New Zealand, South Africa and Rhodesia, fighting German and Italian forces in the Mediterranean and Middle East. Italy had declared war on June , , and its forces invaded Egypt in September that year. In December, the small ,-strong Western Desert Force had counter-attacked and smashed two Italian armies – some , Italians had been captured by February . The British had also attacked Italian-held Abyssinia in East Africa and had pretty much won the day there by May . Germany had struck up an alliance with Italy so that the latter would expand and protect the southern flank of the Reich, but Mussolini’s forces were insufficiently trained and equipped for modern warfare. Smashed by the British, they were also given a bloody nose by the Greeks when they invaded there in October . Hitler felt he had no choice but to intervene. General Erwin Rommel was sent to North Africa with two and then a third ision while German forces also swept into the Balkans and then Greece. Honouring an earlier offer to the Greeks, Britain erted troops from North Africa across the Mediterranean but had neither the air support nor heavy equipment needed to see off the Germans. Most were evacuated from Greece in late April. It was a defeat for both Greece and Britain – as was Crete that followed – but it wasn’t all bad news and these losses need to be seen in their wider context. Crete cost the Germans terribly in terms of half their highly trained paratroopers and most of their transport aircraft – resources they would desperately need in the mammoth clash of arms in the Soviet Union, to be launched a month on in June , . A month later, Britain secured Syria, and rebellions in Iraq and Iran were put down. Later in the year, Rommel’s German-Italian forces in Libya were pushed back again. The Middle East, though important, was not a major oil-producer at the time and its supplies fuelled the British war effort there and in North Africa and no more.  Rather, the leading oil producers in the world – by a country mile – were the US and Venezuela, out of reach for the enemy and the right side of the world for Britain. Fuel was rationed at home but we still used four times as much domestically per year as Germany did in entirety. The biggest setback for Britain was Japan’s entry into the war and the losses of Hong Kong, Singapore, Malaya and Burma. Britain was simply under-prepared in the Far East – its hands were rather full in the west. On the other hand, Japan was unable to reach the jewel in the crown, India, while during the retreat Britain set alight the Burmese oil wells and denied their use to the Japanese.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIn October , General Bernard Montgomery’s Eighth Army counter-attacked at El Alamein, just  miles west of Alexandria. A few months earlier, in June , the British had been smashed near Tobruk and sent packing. It was the lowest point of British generalship in the entire war: a needless defeat caused by bad command decisions and faulty tactics. That the Eighth Army avoided annihilation was largely due to the Desert Air Force, who had developed exciting new tactics for close air support – tactics that would be further honed by the end of the war. General Harold Alexander, Britain’s most experienced commander, and Montgomery were brought in, steadied the ship, then struck back, and this time decisively, sending Rommel’s forces speeding back across Egypt, Libya and into Tunisia. Meanwhile, a joint Anglo-US force landed in pro-Axis French Algeria and Morocco and moved in a pincer movement from the west. By this time, Britain had worked out its way of war, which was to use immense firepower, brought about by a marriage of air, land and sea power. It had realised that German troops always counter-attacked. The moment they did, the Allies would emerge from their foxholes and camouflaged positions and the full weight of their firepower would then rain down upon the Germans – immense artillery, low-level bombers and fighter aircraft, and,close enough, off-shore naval guns too. It meant using a stick to goad them in the first place, which was why being a British infantryman or part of a tank crew was so incredibly dangerous, but it did mean these troops were comparatively few in number. Only around % of the Army were infantry and % were in tanks. Some %, on the other hand, were service troops, maintaining and supplying those at the coal face with food, ammunition, new tanks, trucks, spare parts and medical supplies and so on. Tunisia fell in May , the same month U-boats were largely withdrawn from the Atlantic, which meant the British and Americans could plan operations more effectively as they knew pretty much exactly what supplies were likely to reach them whether in the Mediterranean or in Britain, where preparations had begun for the cross-Channel invasion of France in . In the meantime, British and American troops launched the largest-ever amphibious operation – in terms of numbers of men landed – against Sicily on July , . This was a phenomenally dficult operation logistically, but in a sign of growing confidence, air, land and naval forces worked together to conquer the island in  days, hastening the overthrow of Mussolini. The Allies then invaded southern Italy whilst also building up for Operation Overlord, the invasion of Normandy, which took place on June , , two days after Rome fell. Despite the Americanisation of D-Day, largely thanks to Hollywood, D-Day itself was a predominantly British show. All three service chiefs were British,  of the , warships were British, , of the , landing craft were British, two thirds of the aircraft were British and two thirds of the troops landed were British and Canadian. It is true that American industrial muscle was truly exceptional and yes, the United States did, in many ways, become the Arsenal of Democracy. It was, however, British cash that kick-started this process in  and  and lend-lease ­actually cut both ways: some % of all US supplies in the European Theatre of Operations were provided by us. The Liberty ship, the prefabricated ,-ton merchant vessels churned out by US shipyards, was designed by a Brit, Cyril Thompson, and the initial shipyards on the east and west coasts of the States built with British money. D-Day was, of course, a success, and British forces continued to play a key part in the war in Italy and north-west Europe until the end of the war. Air power remained key to British strategy, and while initially, bombing was inaccurate and underwhelming, by March , when Air Chief Marshal Sir Arthur Harris launched his all-out bombing offensive, Britain had pioneered new navigational aids such as Gee, Oboe, and the first ground-mapping radar, HS, and bombing accuracy improved enormously. The levels of destruction by the RAF’s night bombers were incredible, but regardless of the debates about the morality, it unquestionably had a profoundly detrimental effect on Germany’s ability to wage war. It also saved British lives. The Lancaster bomber and Mosquito were also two incredible designs that played big roles in the air war. What’s more, by the middle of , RAF Bomber Command was able to strike – with unequalled accuracy – not least  Squadron, who earlier on May  and  carried out the successful raid against the German dams. Britain’s approach to war never stood still. In the Far East, the demands were even greater. There were few places in the world more challenging in which to fight. Disease was re, infrastructure almost nonexistent, and the first attempts to re-invade Burma in late  and early  met with failure. Then came monsoon season and a pause for a reappraisal of approach. Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten became Supreme Allied Commander of South East Asia and appointed General Bill Slim as his Army commander. Slim reorganised his supply chains, created new forward units for treating malaria – a disease that struck  men for every one battle casualty – gave every single man jungle combat training, and insisted the RAF win air superiority, which they swtly did with the arrival of superior Spitfires in the autumn of . He dramatically improved morale and his men first withstood a Japanese attack at the Admin Box in the Arakan in north-west Burma in February , then fought a fighting retreat to Imphal in north-east India, before counter-attacking at Kohima and destroying the Japanese Fteenth Army. Part of Slim’s success was his continued harnessing of air power. By commanding the skies, the RAF was able to transport two isions to Imphal as well as make numerous supply drops. Slim pushed the Japanese back into Burma and in spring , he brilliantly caught them out at Meiktila. Mandalay and Rangoon fell soon after and Burma was once again back in British hands. Britain had formed the Pacic Fleet in August  and helped the Americans in the Pacic, not least at Okinawa, in April and May . British scientists also played a vital role in the development of the atom bomb. At home, meanwhile, another agricultural revolution had been going on. In , Britain had produced only % of its own food, but by , that figure was %. This enabled shipping that before the war had been used for food to carry arms and war material instead. Rationing was nothing like as bad as where on the continent. The main purpose was to ensure everyone got a fair and balanced diet. This in turn meant they were fitter and healthier and productivity increased as a result. Britain deserves to feel very proud of the contribution it made in the Second World War and its “steel not flesh” policy. Some , people were killed in the war, and although that is a huge number, it was roughly half that of the First World War – and over nearly six years of a truly global conflict, not four.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThis year marks the th anniversary of one of the most important dates in history.Since , May  has been VE Day, short for Victory in Europe Day. It celebrates the unconditional surrender of Nazi Germany to the Allied forces and the end of World War Two in Europe.Millions of Brits celebrated the news on May  . Prime Minister Winston Churchill led the way with a radio broadcast, a speech to crowds gathered in London and an appearance on the Buckingham Palace balcony alongside the Royal Family. To mark the th anniversary, the traditional May Day bank holiday on the first Monday of the month has been moved to Friday May  for - what was supposed to be three days of celebrations. The end of WW in Europe By April  the Nazi regime was crumbling, with Allied and Soviet forces overrunning Germany from the west and east respectively. Nazi leader Adolf Hitler knew the end was close, and had heard what had happened to Italian dictator Benito Mussolini. Mussolini had been captured by Italian partisans on April . Three days later he was shot and his body hung upside down. The Fuhrer was eager to avoid a similar fate, and on April  killed his dog, his new we Eva Braun and himself in his Berlin bunker. German soldiers started to surrender first in Berlin, then in other parts of Germany and Europe. At .am on May , Nazi high command sent to Reims in France signed the unconditional surrender of German forces.  At first General Alfred Jodl, representing Nazi high command, wanted to surrender to Allied forces on the Western Front. However the Supreme Allied Commander, General Dwight D. Eisenhower, refused and insisted that the Nazis on the Eastern Front must surrender to the Soviet Union, otherwise heaposd end negotiations. The Nazis agreed, and the total surrender was to come into effect the following day, May . VE Day celebrations Celebrations erupted once news reached Britain. It’s estimated that more than a million people celebrated on streets across the UK. Some of the largest crowds gathered in London, with people filling the roads from Trafalgar Square and Whitehall, up The Mall and to Buckingham Palace. In a rousing speech, Churchill told the amassed crowd: “God bless you all. This is your victory! It is the victory of the cause of freedom in every land. In all our long history we have never seen a greater day than this. Everyone, man or woman, has done their best. Everyone has tried. “My dear friends, this is your hour. This is not victory of a party or of any class. Itaposs a victory of the great British nation as a whole. The Prime Minister also appeared on the Buckingham Palace balcony alongside King George VI and Queen Elizabethas well as Princesses Elizabethand Margaret. The young princesses were also allowed to slip out of the palace and join the cheering crowds.  US President Harry Truman celebrated his st birthday on VE Day, and dedicated the victory to his predecessor, Franklin D. Roosevelt. He had died of a cerebral hemorrhage less than a month before VE Day on April . Russia celebrates the end of World War Two in Europe on May . Despite the euphoria, both Churchill and Truman were keen to stress that the war was still going. VJ Day

Lily Burns said she was in the .% of people likely to be badly affected Covid-, but spent a week in sedation in hospital as she fought for her le from the disease. Her organs had swelled up and temperature soared with medics warning she may take a month to be able to speak and walk again, The Daily Record reports. Lily in now recovering at home in Fort William, Scotland, and has shared her harrowing story. I never, ever thought it would happen to me, she said. Iaposm the youngest in the family and have no underlying health conditions so I thought I was the safest from it.to get the Mirror’s daily coronavirus briefing email at  mirror email  -after the press conference every evening. My dad has a lung illness so I had been going out to get the shopping in. Over lockdown I had only been to get prescriptions for my family, doing necessary shopping and anyone I saw was at a two meter distance, my family were laughing at me for going about with a mask on. I was also in the .% of people likely to be badly affected by coronavirus so how could this be so. I really didnapost expect it but it shows that anyone can get coronavirus. Lilyaposs ordeal began on April  when she began feeling shooting pains in her stomach and had her temperature soar to . degrees. Initially medics thought she had a kidney infection and sent home with tablets. But at am the next morning she was woke up with severe pain and vomiting. She said: I woke up and I was being violently sick. We went to A and E at the hospital and they still thought it was a kidney infection.  They performed so many tests, ultrasounds and CT scans, and they tested for coronavirus but it came back negative. The next day I was feeling much better and thought I had gotten over whatever it was. On Wednesday I was up and about on FaceTime to my family, walking round my bedroom, feeling much better then at pm my world flipped and I got another test result back to say that I did in fact have coronavirus and I was going to have to be taken to Raigmore in an ambulance. There was a room filled with doctors and nurses to see me and that was scary. I donapost remember anything after that. Lily was placed on a ventilator under sedation on April . The coronavirus had lodged in her stomach and Lilyaposs organs, including her heart, had began to swell up. But by April , Lily says a miracle happened and the ventilator could be removed as she was breathing by herself. She said: When I woke up I thought I had only been out for a day so was shocked when the nurses said it had been seven. By pm I was on FaceTime to my family I have never been so thankful to see them in my le and by all the crying and “oh my gods” I know they felt the same. It didnapost really realise everything that had happened until I got home and saw all the messages I had missed on my phone. Medics told her that it may take months for her to recover her speech and ability to walk. But she is already on her feet and only speaks slightly slurred.Reward our healthcare heroes now for risking their lives to fight Covid-. We want Chancellor Rishi Sunak to introduce a special daily allowance to be paid to nurses, doctors, support staff and care workers who are risking their lives. But, before you raid your alcohol cupboard, there are a few other essentials you will need, including:Blender Juicer Saucepan Fine-mesh sieve Kitchen scales, measuring cups and spoons Jugs and ladles Moulds and lolly sticksYou will also need to know how to make a simple syrup, which is made up of g of granulated sugar and ml of water. Add your sugar and water to a saucepan on a medium-high heat, and bring to the boil, without stirring. Then, as soon as it starts to boil set a two minute timer. After two minutes, take the pan off the heat and leave it to cool. Transfer to a sealable jar or pot and keep in the fridge for up to a month. Now, onto the good stuff. Watermelon  vodka ice lollies IngredientsA wedge of watermelon  lime Vodka, to serveMethodStart by lining a baking tray with baking paper. Slice a watermelon into triangular pieces around two to three centimetres thick. With a small, sharp kne create a slit in the rind of each wedge - this is where the lolly stick will sit. Pop the wedges on the tray and freeze them overnight - you can then wrap them in baking paper and store in a freezer-proof tub, but, they must be consumed within one week of making. To serve, simple pour a measure of vodka into a glass and place a lolly inside the glass. Tequila Sunrise ice lollies Ingredientsg strawberries ml grenadine syrup Juice of  lime ml simple syrup ml fresh orange juice ml silver tequila  MethodUsing a kne create a hole in the top of the each strawberry. To a blender, add your strawberries, grenadine syrup and half the lime juice - mix until smooth. Add the mixture to your ice lolly moulds and freeze to two to three hours, or until slushy. Then, to a jug, add the leftover lime juice, the orange juice, simple syrup and tequila, stir well and add directly on top of the strawberry mixture. Insert the lolly sticks and freeze overnight until solid.

The compound called liquiritin was found to have prevented the rapid replication of the virus strain in monkey cells, according to reports. title: dundee fc james mcpake transfers
story: James McPake has assured fans Dundee will be ready to hit the ground running after the coronavirus shutdown but admits the club “cannot go out and offer someone a three-year deal at the moment”.The Dens Park gaffer says he’s doing everything he can to prepare for next season, whenever it might start, despite the entire playing staff being put on furlough leave.With no indication yet when football will restart, clubs are understandably not in a position to sign new players – McPake, though, says he’s doing all he can to be ready for when the transfer market kicks back into le.The Dens gaffer said: “It has been an ongoing process since last summer.“We certainly cannot go out and offer someone a three-year deal at the moment.“But what is never going to stop or change is that we firmly believe we have a process in place for recruitment.“It has to get better but the fundamentals of what we do won#t change.“We have been working on this since last summer with regards to the January transfer window and then this summer’s transfer window.“So it is still ongoing. Hopefully, when the time#s right and everybody is safe, we need to make sure we are ready to go.”Dundee have been heavily linked with afor striker Simon Murray, who is a free agent after leaving South African side Bidvest Wits last month, while a permanent move for St Johnstone midfielder Ross Callachan could also be on the cards.His loan spell at Dens was ended prematurely with a broken leg but impressed in his short time there and is out of contract in the summer.McPake has also never hidden his desire to see Hearts forward Craig Wighton back with the Dark Blues.The current concern for teams like Dundee in the lower isions, however, is how next campaign might look.The SPFL have begun a league reconstruction task force led by Hearts chair Ann Budge and Hamilton chief Les Gray to revamp the setup for the new campaign.Dens Park managing director John Nelms is part of the -strong reconstruction group but McPake admits he’ll be happy with whatever future is decided, as long as it benefits the game as a whole.He added: “My preferred option is that we just find a way to get something that works.“Look, we need to make sure everything is safe first.“Do I have a preferred option  I would love to be in the Premiership but we had a chance to do that ourselves this season and we failed.“If we had won the league, it would have been a given.“Butreconstruction happens, whatever way, I just hope they do it so that it suits the game going forward.“Would our input as managers help  But do we then ask players as well “It is a tough one. Do I want to be involved  No, I am happy to leave it to the powers-that-be and just concentrate on my job getting our squad ready so that when we do get the green light to go ahead we can do that.“I just want football back, I think society wants football back andreconstruction comes in then great.“But there are people out there risking their lives to save lives so they are the real important ones.” months free access to our web and ePaper pack including Premium articles.

story: North-east beer giant BrewDog has announced that three wind turbines will soon be providing the power for its north-east base.It is part of a bid by the firm to become more sustainable.Group part of the BrewDog tomorrow programme, which launched just a few months ago.The scheme aims to make a number of dferent changes within the company, in order to make it sustainable and more environmentally friendly.David McDowall, said: #It#s our commitment to becoming  a more responsible and sustainable organisation.#The end goal is that we think we can set an example by becoming the most sustainable brewery on the planet.#As well as the wind turbine project we#ve completely ditched plastic from all our packaging and we#re working on an anaerobic digestion project which allows us to take all of the waste water we use in the brewing process and turn it into clean water and reuse it.#The business has made progress already with its cans for equity scheme, which asks customers toBrewDog cans in batches of .The cans are recycled, and the aluminium is ed to the packaging industry # saving  energy, reducing CO emissions and erting the cans from landfill.As a reward, customers they will provide us with . megawatts of clean electricity and that#s enough for us to power our entire brewery operation with clean energy.#The company now export to over  markets and have bars and relaunch the business once given the go-ahead by the government, and are implementing ways to ensure the safety of all of their customers during the coronavirus outbreak.This includes contactless title: aberdeens route to 1990 scottish cup the last time the dons lifted the national trophy
story: On Monday, it will be  years since Aberdeen last lted the Scottish Cup, famously defeating Celtic on penalties at Hampden to complete a domestic cup double.There have been near misses since the Reds lted the old trophy for the seventh time, none closer than when current manager Derek McInnes# team lost - to the Hoops in .Although members of the Red Army who weren#t even born by  will have likely seen Theo Snelders# shoot-out save from Anton Rogan before Brian Irvine fired himself and the   squad # bossed by Alex Smith and Jocky Scott # into the history books, there will be some who don#t know the full story of the Dons# run in the competition that year.The League Cup-winning Dons started their Scottish Cup quest away to eventual First Division mid-tablers Partick in what would turn out to be goal bonanza.There was no Willie Miller, Theo Snelders, Hans Gillhaus or David Robertson due to injury, while midfield maestro Jim Bett was suspended, meaning the likes of Michael Watt, Ian Robertson and Willem van der Ark all started.Callum Campbell scored for the Jags after two minutes, after the ball squirmed under Watt, before big Dutchman Van der Ark levelled from Alex McLeish#s low cross.In what was an underwhelming start to a thrilling cup campaign, centre-back Irvine # Miller#s heir apparent # then chopped down Campbell to give away a penalty, and Chic Charnley put the home side back in front.However, an angled finish from Brian Grant before the break made it - and seemed to extinguish any Thistle fire.In the second half, Van der Ark lashed home another, Jim Kerr headed Paul Mason#s cross into his own net, before Skol Cup hero Mason made it - # despite being brought down in the build-up to his lofted finish # and Van der Ark completed his hat-trick with a perfectly-placed low effort from the edge of the area.Smith and Scott#s charges got off to a shocking start at rain-soaked Pittodrie in this one, gting the First Division strugglersan opener from a free-kick hoofed from half-way which Tommy Turner turned past Bobby Mimms.Both sides hit the woodwork chasing the second goal of the game, with Charlie Nicholas also seeing a one-on-one effort saved.The Dons must have been given a rollicking in the Pittodrie dressing room at half-time, though. Hans Gillhaus headed the equaliser from Mason#s cross soon after the break, and # after a few close calls # Nicholas eventually smashed home from close range after the ball was poked through to him by Bobby Connor. Phew.Long-time skipper Willie Miller was again missing for this last-eight clash, during what was a frustrating season for the great one, and didn#t play again in Aberdeen#s Scottish Cup run. He had suffered a knee injury on Scotland duty against Norway in November , which would ultimately end his career.Still, the Dons # in what would become a procession to the final # made light work of the Jambos.Midfield dynamo Jim Bett scored the opener, cutting in off the left and sending an early shot past Henry Smith. The Reds were in charge, but John Colquhoun would later equalise after a stramash at a corner.After the break Aberdeen ran away with it, Stewart McKimmie, Nicholas and Gillhaus combining for their second, before final hero Irvine lashed home to make it -.The fourth saw Gillhaus nutmeg Walter Kidd out wide, before repaying the favour with a cutback for Nicholas to finish.Smith and Scott surprised everyone by including full-back David Robertson in their line-up for the last-four meeting at Tynecastle. He#d been out for months with a serious foot injury.Keeper Snelders also ed from a knee complaint. These s and sense of things coming together were perhaps, in hindsight, a sign Aberdeen#s glory day at Hampden was meant to be.In what turned out to be a rout, final hero Irvine opened the scoring when he turned home Nicholas# cross from close range after Alan Main had saved his first effort.Just before half-time, future Don Mixu Paatelainen headed a high ball into the Tangerines# area past his own goalkeeper to make it -.The Reds# third was another nightmare for United, when Freddy van der Hoorn # under  a little bit of pressure from Mason # comically hoofed the ball over Main from the edge of the area.There was no fortune about the goal to make it -, however, Dutch wizard Gillhaus taking down a long ball on the left of the box and thumping it low beyond the United goalie. Aberdeen were in the final at a canter.The part of story even the Dons fans who weren#t around to see it know.After a goalless  minutes, there was no other way to settle the Hampden showpiece other than penalty kicks. Dariusz Wdowczyk missed the Hoops# opener, before Grant failed to score with penalty number four for the Dons.Aberdeen#s Nicholas # set to join Celtic after the summer # was notably successful with his effort to level things at - and send the shoot-out to sudden death.On the unbearable tension of the moment from that point onwards, captain and penalty-taker number six McLeish told the Evening Express in January: “God, aye.the penalty, the penalty I had to take.“It wasn’t the winning penalty, but it was a pretty important one. It was number six.“Celtic had taken five, we had taken five and one player from each team had missed.“I rememberJocky Scott saying ‘who’s taking the next one ’ and I said ‘I’ll take it’.“He asked ‘are you confident you’re going to score ’ and I said ‘not really, but I don’t see anyone  volunteering’.“So I took the long walk up, decided to stick to my favourite position, hitting to the goalkeeper’s left as hard and accurate as I could. If I did that I knew he wouldn’t save it.“I scored. But I didn’t jump up and celebrate. I walked back thinking ‘thank … goodness’.”Eventually, Rogan#s penalty was saved by Snelders, before Irvine blasted the winner to secure the trophy.McLeish added: “By the time we got to - and Brian won it, the goalies were ing the wrong way and people were mis-kicking it and it was going in.“We thought it was never going to end.“Then Theo Snelders, as he said at his hall of fame induction, said he knew it was coming close to him taking one, so knew he had to save one – that was Anton Rogan.“It was a great, great save. Theo timed it really well.” months free access to our web and ePaper pack including Premium articles.
