title: borders-gp-practices-stay-open-early-may-bank-holiday
story: HEALTH centres and GP practices in the Borders will remain open on Friday, despite the public holiday.The early May bank holiday is taking place on May  to coincide with VE Day.But NHS Borders wants to let people know that they will still be able to contact their health centres and practices over the phone.Patients should not attend in person unless told to do so, according to NHS Borders.Meanwhile, some community pharmacies will also remain open on Friday.For information on your local pharmacys opening hours, you can click here.The early May bank holiday usually takes place on the first Monday of the month.

title: galashiels-postman-wears-superhero-costume-round
story: A GALASHIELS postman has been wearing a superhero costume while delivering parcels.James Morley, , of Melrose, raises a chuckle on his round by donning an Iron Man suit with his high-vis vest.Mr Morley said: "If people smile or laugh because of me, thats all I wanted."The stunt has been particularly popular with older residents, according to Mr Morley.He said: "Older people are at home and havent been able to see their grandchildren and families."A lot of them wanted the photos so they could say that Iron Man delivered their post."Ive had people whove missed me asking me to come back round again so they can get photos and their children can see me through the window."But Mr Morley, based at Galashiels Delivery Office, might not be the only superhero postie in town for much longer.He told the Border : "I may have convinced colleagues to join me. Were trying to organise a day when we can all dress up."Most of my colleagues, when I said I was going to do this, they didnt believe me until I walked into the office."It is unclear whether other members of the Marvel Avengers will join Mr Morley, but some residents are already suggesting he showcase other superheroes, including Spiderman and Batman.For now, however, Mr Morley and his colleagues ndash in costume or not ndash are continuing to provide their key service in abnormal circumstances."Our job has changed drastically," Mr Morley said. "In some respects its easier, leaving parcels at the door for contactless deliveries, but its a bit like Christmas as everyones at home so theyre ordering more as they cant go out."Its like Christmas but with fewer staff, too."Were just trying our best to press on with bringing parcels and letters to people."If you know of any other key workers going above and beyond to improve peoples days during lockdown, get in touch by emailing editorial@bordertelegraph or by messaging our Facebook page at www.facebook bordertelegraph

title: whirlpool-washing-machine-recall-extended-models---full-list
story: An additional  washing machines and tumble dryers haved been recalled by Whirlpool after being deemed to be a fire risk.Heres what you need to doyou have an affected model.What hasWhirlpool said The update comes from the Whirlpool website as ofApril , which states: ldquoAs part of ongoing in-depth checks carried out by Whirlpoolrsquos safety team, we are adding  additional models to the recall.The machines are being recalled because, as Whirlpool explains:ldquoWhen the heating element in the washing machine is activated, in very rare cases a component in the door lock system can overheat, which, depending on product features, can pose a risk of fire.If you have already checked your machine due to previous recalls, you will need to check it again.The recalled washing machines were manufactured under the brands of Hotpoint and Indesit between  and .The full list of recalled modelsThese are the recalled models that have been added to the list of recalled machines by Whirlpool:WMAQB P UKWMAQB P UKWMAQB G UKWMAQB P UKWMAQF P UK.LWMAQF G UKWMAQF P UKWMAQF P UKWMAQG G UKWMAQG P UKWMAQG P UKWMAQG P UK.MWMAQG P UK.MWMAQL P UKWMAQL P UKWMAQL A UKWMAQL P UKWMAQL P UK.MWMAQL G UKWMAQL P UKWMSAQG G UKHow to checkyoursquore affectedIf you think your washing machine is affected by the recall,head to the dedicated Whirlpool recall website-washingmachinerecall.whirlpool.Yoursquoll need to enter your postcode and your model number, and the website will be able to tell youyour model is part of the recall.If it is, yoursquoll then be taken to a new page which asks you to register, which will allow Whirlpool to get in contact with you.Yoursquoll need to fill out your name, email address, phone number and home address. Yoursquoll also need to state where you bought the machine from as well.Alternatively, you can phone   .What happensmy machine is being recalled If your machine is affected by the recall, then you are advised to unplug your appliance and stop using it immediately.If you must continue using it, you should use only a cold water cycle of  degrees celsius or lower.This will stop the washing machinersquos heating element from being activated and therefore poses less of a risk.Whirlpool Vice President, Jeff Noel, said:ldquoWe will still continue to provide a free-of-charge replacement of comparable specication or in-home engineering repair to all affected customers in as safe a way as possible.ldquoWe understand that in the current climate, some customers will have health and safety concerns around our delivery partners or engineers entering their homes to carry out replacements or repairs.ldquoWe continue to follow government guidelines, with strict health and safety processes across our operations, including equipping all our delivery drivers and engineers with personal protective equipment and hand sanitiser.ldquoHowever, we will also offer customers the option of contactless delivery and removal of affected appliances.

title: melrose-shops-praise-volunteers-free-deliveries-start
story: TRADERS in Melrose have joined forces to offer free delivery to customers who are unable to leave their homes.Butcher Martin Baird, , has recruited a raft of volunteer drivers to serve products from his shop and three others.Mr Baird said customer feedback has been ldquogreat, adding: ldquoWe had nearly  deliveries today ndash itrsquos really gone bananas.Other businesses taking part in the scheme are the Country Kitchen Deli, the Premier newsagent and vegetable shop Purple Plum.Mr Baird, whose shop has been on the high street for  years, said at least  people have volunteered to deliver.ldquoI try to give them payment, but they wonrsquot accept it ndash so I just give them a bit of meat, he told the Border .Drop-offs are being made in Galashiels almost every day, said Mr Baird, with some households in Stow, Bowden and Kelso also seeking help.Mr Baird said his business has always been popular, but demand has shot up during the coronavirus lockdown.He said: ldquoIrsquove taken on a couple of youngsters just for this period andthis keeps up, I might have to employ a couple more, because I canrsquot keep working  hours a week.Ready-made meals are proving to be a major hit, Mr Baird said. Big sellers include roast beef, lasagne and sweet and sour dishes.ldquoThe amount of mince Irsquove sold is just incredible. And wersquove got a full-time pie man and hersquos just having to work his socks off, Mr Baird said, adding: ldquoWersquore the lucky ones, being busy ndash I feel for some people.In a joint statement, the four shop owners said they are ldquoincredibly thankful for the help provided by volunteers.Commending their efforts, the statement added: ldquoThey are actively committed to continuing to provide this essential doorstep service to all those who require it.

title: jack-lowden-invites-entries-earlston-high-talent-show
story: ACTOR Jack Lowden has urged pupils at Earlston High School to take part in a talent competition.The former Earlston student starred in a video on Facebook this week appealing for entries to Earlstonrsquos Got Virtual Talent.Lowden invited pupils to submit video clips of themselves doing "something really cool and extraordinary".The -second clips should be sent through Show My Homework, he said, between May  and June .Giving examples of the talent being sought, Lowden said performances may showcase cooking, acting, singing, dancing, football skills or dog routines.When entries are received, judges will whittle them down to a shortlist and then the public will vote for the winner."There will be an almighty bonanza of a prize for the person that wins," said Lowden, calling on pupils to "have some fun".Lowden, who received an Olivier Award in , has appeared in films including Dunkirkand Mary, Queen of Scots.

title: mays-super-flower-moon-see-uk
story: A so-called lsquoFlower Moonrsquo will be spotted over the skies of the UK this week.Not only that, but Mays full moon will also be a supermoon, making it a Super Flower Moon.But just what does all that mean What is a Flower Moon The May full moon is traditionally known as the Flower Moon simply because it appears at the time of blossoming flowers.What is a supermoon The moon - our planets only natural satellite - actually follows an elliptical orbit around the Earth.This means that at certain points on its egg-shaped path, it can be further away, or closer to us - a dferential of about , miles.The closest point is called the perigee, and the furthest is the apogee. When a full moon falls on the perigee, it appears far bigger and brighter in the sky and becomes known as a supermoon.The phenomenon is not actually that rare, and this months is last in a trilogy that began with Marchs full moon..During a supermoon,the diameter of the moon canappear to be about  per cent greater than an average full moon.What timewill the moon be biggest The full moon will be in the night sky on the evening of Thursday, May , though it will technically be at its fullest at :am on Thursday morning.Seeing as it wont even be in the sky then - let alone visible in daylight - the fullest youll get to see the moon will come at around .pm on Thurday, when the moon rises.It will be in the sky all night, and wont set again until about .am the following morning, offering plenty of time for you to catch a glimpse.For the best effect ndash and the closest yoursquoll get to witnessing the spectacular images seen across social media following such an event ndash yoursquoll want to look east shortly after moonrise.ldquoWhen the moon is near the horizon, it can look unnaturally large when viewed through trees, buildings, or other foreground objects," say NASA."The effect is an optical illusion, but that fact doesnrsquot take away from the experience."What  should I look out for This months full moon ties in nicely with the peak of the Eta Aquariids meteor shower.The meteor shower has been going on above our heads for a couple of weeks, and runs roughly from April  - May .However, it is this week when budding astronomers are likely to get the best show, as the shower peaks on the night of May  into May .The Eta Aquariids should be visible with the naked eye, although the glare from a full supermoon will make them harder to spot.Those living in built up areas would usually be advised to travel to less populated spaces and to avoid light pollutionthey really want to see the shower, but with ongoing lockdown restrictions and the coronavirus pandemic, that is not advised.Wrapping up in warm clothes is recommended, and you should allow up to  minutes for your eyes to fully adjust to the night sky.The Eta Aquariids are not one of the years most spectacular meteor showers, and usually peak at around  meteors per hours - thats just under one a minute.

title: caring-woman-guarding-door-borders-chemist
story: WHEN the Peebles Fat Face store closed its doors along with every other shop on the High Street, assistant manager Jane McGarry wasnrsquot home for long before going back to work.No sooner had she hung up the closed sign, Jane began a new voluntary post at a vital store directly opposite.She explained: ldquoWe closed on the Saturday before lockdown. I saw a post for help in Boots chemist on the COVID support page on the Monday morning and was in Boots an hour later.Janersquos new role involves manning the door of the chemist as people queue to pick up medicines.ldquoI roughly do five or six hours a day, Monday to Saturday," she said."My main role is basically to make sure I only let two people in the shop at a time.ldquoThe public are great and understanding. I also take repeat prescriptions so people donrsquot have to queue.Jane joked that she probably now knows the layout in Boots better than she does in Fat Face.ldquoIrsquom getting to know where things are in the shop so I can assist people," she said, adding: ldquoIt feels great to do my bit, evenit is just a cheery face or a friendly hello."While Jane helps people by handing in prescriptions, Peebles student Annie Patterson has proved a dab hand at delivering them.Annie is studying veterinary nursing at Edinburgh Napier University and was due to start her summer placement before the coronavirus outbreak.She said: ldquoAt the beginning of the pandemic, I saw that the NHS was recruiting volunteers throughout the UK."I asked Danielle at Bootsthey needed a hand delivering prescriptions. I wanted to use this time I now had available to help others.ldquoI have been doing this Monday to Saturday for six weeks now and itrsquos great because the majority of people are so grateful."

title: 65th-anniversary-couple-met-galashiels-academy
story: A COUPLE will celebrate their th anniversary today by speaking to family over Zoom.Charlie and Evelyn Renton, of St Boswells, were married on May , , at Melrose Parish Church.With coronavirus restrictions in place, a traditional family reunion is not possible ndash but the pair have been looking forward to a virtual get-together.Reflecting on their long marriage, Mrs Renton, , said: ldquoWersquove been very happy and healthy and very lucky.The couple, who first met at Galashiels Academy, moved from Mr Rentonrsquos native Galashiels to the Republic of Ireland in .Mrs Renton, originally from Melrose, had qualied as a nurse in Edinburgh, while Mr Renton, , enjoyed a career as a textile designer.The couple have three children , three grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.They ed to the Borders in , moving into their current home in St Boswells.

title: ve-day-75th-anniversary-2-coin-much-may-worth---get-one
story: To mark the th anniversary of VE Day -the Royal Mint has released a commemorative pound coin.Hereseverything you need to know about the new collection from the Royal Mint - including how to get your hands on a coin and how much it costs.Why has the Royal Mint made a commemorative coin The Royal Mint website says: ldquoSeventy-fiveyears on [from VE Day], we thank the generation who gave so much and honour their spirit and sacrice.VE Day stands for Victory in Europe Day, and it refers to May , , when Germany surrendered their armed forces during World War II.The coin from the Royal Mint aims to ldquoremember the first hopeful steps towards lasting peace and the promise of a brighter future.The isional director of commemorative coins at the Royal Mint, Clare Maclennan, said that she hoped the VE Day coins would bring Britain together during the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.Maclennan said: ldquoOur VE Day commemorative coin was inspired by a shared sense of community and loyalty.ldquoDuring these challenging times that the nation finds itself in, we may be unable to join with our loved ones to mark this national milestone, but it feels especially important that we come together to protect the older generation that sacriced so much for us.What coins are available to buy If you want to get your hands on the commemorative pound coin from the Royal Mint, you have a few options.The th anniversary of VE Day pound uncirculated coin comes in educational packaging all about VE Day and Winston Churchill. This costs pound.There is also the th anniversary of VE Day silver proof pound coin. This coin is limited edition, with only , made. It costs pound..Next is the th anniversary of VE Day piedfort silver pound coin. Also limited edition, only , have been made. This coin costs pound.Last is the th anniversary of VE Day gold proof pound coin. This is also an extremely limited edition coin, as only  were made. This coin costs pound,.Alternatively, you can purchase a th anniversary of VE Day gold proof pound coin with a period newspaper, which allows you to read the news of VE Day as it was reported from an original period newspaper.This is an extremely limited edition package with only  available to buy. It costs pound, and because itrsquos so rare, yoursquoll need to phone The Royal Mint on    to place an order.For each coin purchased, a donation will be made to the Imperial War Museums.What do the coins look like The coins feature a design which shows the celebrating public with the word lsquovictoryrsquo across the top.Designer Dominique Evans said: ldquoIconic images of VE Day serve to remind us of the magnitude of events.ldquoMillions came together in the streets to celebrate the end of the war in Europe, inspiring me to put the people at the very heart of this coin. The rays evoke search lights, a familiar sight in the skies during wartime, except here they represent rays of home.

title: uks-first-skytyping-display-marks-ve-day
story: The UKrsquos first skytyping display has been conducted, to mark VE Day and pay tribute to frontline workers.Messages such as We Will Meet Again and Thank You were etched in the sky above Henstridge airfield in Somerset.The display was commissioned by the Department for Transport, which recently introduced a law change to allow skytyping and skywriting to take place.vw,vw,px, px"One of the messages read ldquowersquoll meet again The techniques were made illegal in the UK in the s over safety concerns, but are used in many countries such as the US, Australia, France and Spain.Skywriting was inadvertently discovered by an RAF pilot during the First World War, when oil accidentally entered a planersquos exhaust, creating dense, white smoke.According to the DfT, skytyping, which involves smoke being emitted in a series of bursts, was not conducted in the UK before Fridayrsquos display in Somerset.vw,vw,px, px"The display was commissioned by the Department for Transport Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said: ldquoVictory in Europe Day will always be a landmark in British history and it is an honour to have commissioned the first skytyping display in the UK to mark the occasion.ldquoWith its strong British history, stemming from the creation of skywriting, it seems an entirely fitting way to honour all those who fought for our freedom while also thanking those keeping the country moving during this challenging time.Countryside charity CPRE has previously warned that allowing skytyping and skywriting would ldquorob people of the ldquoregenerative benefits of a rural walk.The DfT decided that benefits such as creating jobs for pilots and inspiring children to take up a career in aviation outweighed any negatives..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: UK us first skytyping display marks VE Day

title: sisters-transform-bar-musselburghs-friendliest-pub
story: Rebecca and Victoria Fowler took over The Sportsman Bar in May last year, with a view to transforming the High Street premises.The venue has signed up to Best Bar None Scotland and Rebecca, of Tranent, felt it had made a massive dference in turning the business around.She said: ldquoHaving previously worked in The Sportsman, we knew what we were taking on but also knew it was something we could make work.ldquoThe pub had a bit of a reputation. We wanted to turn it into a safe place for people to come and enjoy a night out with a bit of banter thrown in: lsquoMusselburghrsquos friendliest pub.rsquo But we knew this wouldnrsquot happen overnight.Best Bar None Scotland aims to ensure everyone can enjoy a safe night out.The national scheme, which works through a partnership between local authorities, the Scottish Government, Police Scotland, Scottish Fire and Rescue Service and other organisations, works to reduce crime, reward excellence, and raise standards of alcohol licensed premises.Rebecca added: ldquoLicensing recommended trouble and actively promote initiatives like lsquoAsk Angelarsquo.ldquoWe even hand out lollipops at the end of busy nights to help reduce noise.ldquoWe know that when our patrons leave the pub they enjoyable and a safe night out.

title: extension-planned-school-prestonpans
story: East Lothian Council wants to add two classrooms to the east side of St Gabrielrsquos RC Primary School, in Prestonpans, as more housing being built in the town is expected to increase the title: royal-mail-stop-saturday-letter-deliveries-due-coronavirus-pandemic
story: It said it will continue to provide its letter delivery service from Monday to Friday as normal and said customers ldquoshould continue to post both letters and parcels as usual on Saturday.Royal Mail will continue to collect all mail from businesses, post offices and post boxes, it said.When will Saturday deliveries temporarily stop The will be halted from this weekend .What have Royal Mail said Shane OrsquoRiordain, managing director of marketing, regulation and corporate affairs at Royal Mail, said: ldquoOur postmen and postwomen are working very hard across the UK in challenging conditions.ldquoAs we said at the start of the coronavirus crisis, there will be some disruption to services.ldquoWe understand the importance of the postal service in keeping the UK connected at this time.ldquoWe have also listened to our hard-working colleagues who have asked us to ease the additional burden on thempossible. As a result, we are making some temporary changes to postal services.Royal Mail said it has been in dialogue with the Government and regulator Ofcom throughout the crisis and will keep the temporary change to postal arrangements under review.Reaction to the moveThe decision was criticised by the Communication Workersrsquo Union , which represents postal workers.A CWU spokesman said: ldquoWe will be seeking urgent discussions with the Government on this issue.ldquoThe reduction of the Universal Service Obligation was a key factor in our live national strike ballot.ldquoThe last thing we want to do is call strike action at this point but we will not sit back and see our membersrsquo jobs put at threat and the service to the public worsened.Last month the union called for householdsrsquo deliveries to be cut to three days a week due to coronavirus.

title: teachers-well-placed-assess-students-grades
story: The Scottish Qualications Authorityhas revealed how it aims to determine the  exam results for students due to sit them, following the suspension of normal examinations due to Covid-.And Lesley Brown, the councilrsquos chief operating officer for education, said schools were prepared to provide the evidence needed and review the results using their professional judgement.She said: ldquoWe know that the closure of schools and the cancellation of exams has caused anxiety and uncertainty for our pupils and their families. Irsquom pleased that the SQA has now confirmed its approach, and I am especially pleased to see recognition that teachers and schools are best-placed to provide a judgement on pupilsrsquo achievements.ldquoOur schools regularly monitor and track pupilsrsquo progress throughout the academic year as part of our approaches to ensuring high-quality learning, teaching and assessment. Teachersrsquo professional judgement is at the heart of our approach in Scotland and our teachers are very well placed to provide the information required by SQA.ldquoWe are working with our headteachers and school teams to make sure that our approach across East Lothian is consistent, rigorous and accurately reflects pupilsrsquo achievements. Our teachers will estimate grades using all evidence available to them, with support from their subject faculties, wider school teams and from our central education team.The SQA says its approach to awarding grades is based on safe and secure certication following public health advice and maintaining the integrity and credibility of the qualications system.Schools and colleges will be asked to provide the SQA with estimates on pupilsrsquo achievements, grades, bands and rank based on their performance so far in subject activities.This will provide an overall judgement from those the SQA describes as ldquobest placed to do so, with submissions due by May .The SQA will then check and validate the estimates it receives and look at prior assessments undertaken by pupilsthey are available ndash for example, Higher results for an Advanced Higher pupil.The schoolsrsquo previous history in estimating attainment will be considered and SQA will hold Awarding Meetings with its subject experts.Results will be delivered to learners by August  and students are encouraged to register for MySQA to receive their results by text and or email.The appeals process will remain free for schools and colleges so they can advocate on their pupilsrsquo behalfthe results do not reflect the candidatersquos achievements.The SQA has an exams QA for parents and pupils on its website, www.sqa.org.uk

title: pubs-may-limit-drinkers-three-pints-lockdown-lifted
story: Heres what you need to know.What social distancing rules could pubs face When pubs reopen for business, patrons could be limited to three drinks each before being asked to head home, in order to free up space for others to visit, a government advisor has suggested.The strict rules would also include maintaining a social distance of two metres while inside, with landlords able to issue fines to those who flout the rules.The terms are outlined in a plan by economist and government advisor, Professor Eyal Winter, who said social distancing is the key to coming out of lockdown. They are an important part of British culture.ldquoOne of the most important things is to have a programme, to say, lsquoIn two weeks we will do such and such.rsquoldquoYou need to make the rules crystal clear, and to explain to the public the rationale behind each one of them.When are pubs likely to reopen Professor Winter estimated that it will take ldquoa lot of time to move back to how le was in January , but was certain that the country ldquowill get there.The Mail Online has reported that a possible exit plan could see the UK come out of lockdown in phases. title: bridges-project-continues-vital-work-lockdown
story: Regular face-to-face sessions and group activities at the Bridges Project on Bogpark Road have been replaced with phone calls, text messages, video calls and digital work as the lockdown becomes challenging for some.Despite the dficult times as a result of the pandemic, staff have discovered ldquopositive elements of lsquoremotersquo working with young people in East Lothian and Midlothian. story: The centre is working with Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council on the initiative, with staff at the centre cooking the meals.More than  volunteers at the local resilience group are helping with packing and deliveries.As many as  families are receiving hot meals or food donations, with deliveries made every day. title: goblin-ha-inspires-author-release-first-fantasy-novel
story: Goblin Hall, described as ldquoa humour-laced fantasy adventure for all the family, marks the latest chapter in the ied career of Peter Kerr.Widely known for his Snowball Oranges and Bob Burns Investigates series, he has turned his hand to another genre, with a nod towards The Goblin Harsquo, a reputedly haunted chamber that lies beneath the ruins of Yester Castle, near Gford.He said: ldquoI actually wrote the story, I think, about  years ago.ldquoIt was when my first book, Snowball Oranges, was just coming out, after waiting about  years to get published.ldquoI had an agent in London at the time and she said the way I write is very visual and I should have a go at writing a film script.ldquoI had never even read one but took her at her word and looked at the layout and general routine for laying down film scripts.ldquoAs for the The Goblin Harsquo, I had been to the old castle, with one of my pals who lived in Gford, when we were both about  way back in the s.ldquoThe place itself was not much to see, except peeking into the underground chamber, which inspired me.ldquoIt was bloody frightening and a very spooky place ndash it stuck in my mind.It was only two years ago, when transferring stories to a new computer, that Peter revisited his original film script and set about creating the novel.The legend of the Goblin Harsquo states that Sir Hugo de Gfard, known as the Wizard of Yester, made a pact with the devil to raise a magical army, who he used to carry out his will.Peterrsquos new tale, which is available from Amazon, features an evil sorcerer called Zorn, who has lured two young children into his subterranean lair as bait to ensnare his arch rival, a wizard called Mungo.It is up to the lovable but dippy old wizard to help free the youngsters from Zornrsquos clutches.The author, of Haddingtonrsquos Chalybeate, said feedback about the story was ldquoquite encouraging.That came despite the -year-old making an interesting revelation to the Courier. He said: ldquoI honestly donrsquot think I have ever read a fantasy novel!ldquoThat same literary agent, when she was trying to get a publisher for Snowball Oranges, told me detective novels were always popular.ldquoIrsquove never read one of those either and she said, lsquowell,you write one it will be original, evenit is rubbishrsquo.ldquoThat was the same attitude I took towards writing the fantasy novel.ldquoThe reaction so far has been quite encouraging.Peter was in popular s jazz band the Clyde Valley Stompers, who charted with Peter and The Wolf and were supported by The Beatles before the Fab Four made it big.Later, Peter produced more than  albums ndash including the Royal Scots Dragoon Guardsrsquo international chart-topper Amazing Grace ndash the biggest-selling instrumental of all time with  million sales.Thank you for reading this story. title: lockdown-birthday-proves-one-remember-neighbours-wave
story: Ian Millar has been recovering from heart bypass surgery at his home in Haddington and, under lockdown guidelines, has been staying in.However, daughter Susan was determined to make sure his landmark birthday did not go unmarked, and decorated his car with balloons and a poster asking passers-by to wave to her dad.And, last Friday, lots of families out for their daily walk stopped to do just that.Susan said: ldquoDad has not been able to get out of the house and is recovering from his operation so I wanted to surprise him. title: thirty-seven-new-homes-given-green-light-dunbar
story: Thirty-seven new homes on the outskirts of Dunbar were given the go ahead, despite concerns lodged by the community council.The statutory consultee contacted East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department when Harrison Hunt Ltd and Hallhill Developments Ltdrsquos plans were submitted in November last year.The scheme, which was approved at the beginning of the month, is a mix of three and four-bedroom homes on the south-west corner of the Hallhill area.Community councillors outlined  concerns with the proposals, including the layout and footpath provision, as well as the effects on habitat and the increased demand on education provision in the town.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of the group, said it could be ldquoincredibly depressing to feel the views of the community council were not being given full consideration.She said: ldquoAll the comments we continue to make about connectivity, safe routes to school, play spaces, maximising potential for ecological building... all of that and we just feel asit is ignored.ldquoIt will not stop us making the comments but it does sometimes feel aswe are whistling in the wind.The development, to the west of Yosemite Park and Fall Avenue, will consist of: four three-bedroom terraced homes  three-bedroom detached and semi-detached properties  four-bedroom detached homes and four four-bedroom semi-detached houses.The proposals were approved by the local authorityrsquos planning department, which said the homes would be ldquoappropriate to their location given their height, size and scale.The planning officer added: ldquoThe proposed residential development would provide an attractive residential environment. The residential units are shown to be laid out in such a way that adheres to the normally accepted privacy and amenity criteria on overlooking and overshadowing, whilst affording the future occupants of the residential units an appropriate level of privacy and residential amenity.Access to the new development would come from Fall Avenue and James Kirk Way.A design and access statement included within the planning application notes meetings had taken place with ious local authority departments in a bid to address ious design requirements.It concludes: ldquoOverall, it is considered that the final design creates a well-considered, proportionate design that responds to the site constraints and the nearby area to create a positive design solution.ldquoThe result is a development that will make a positive contribution socially, economically and aesthetically to the area and enhance the amenity of existing and future residents within this area.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council stressed they ldquowelcomed comments from community councils.She said: ldquoIn this case, we consulted the community council back in December, and they submitted a response detailing a number of concerns.ldquoThese included concerns over house type and layout, increased vehicle movement and parking space provision.ldquoWhilst we understand that consultees may be frustrated when planning authorities do not always agree with their comments, we must balance these comments against the other material considerations of each case.ldquoIn the case of the Hallhill application, our conclusion was that, subject to the imposition of conditions, the proposed development was acceptable.Thank you for reading this story. title: grey-squirrels-targeting-dirleton-bowling-clubs-clubhouse
story: Dirleton Bowling Club, which dates back almost  years, is aiming to refurbish its clubhouse because of the troublesome creatures.A new roof would be included in the works, which are being weighed up by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.Improvements to the footpath would also be included but a design and access statement in the planning application highlights that it is squirrels which are the problem.It reads: ldquoThe catalyst for this improvement project is the extensive ongoing damage to the existing clubhouse roof caused by grey squirrels nesting in the roof during the past three winters.ldquoThey penetrate between the pantiles and nest underneath them, gnawing their way through to the clubroom itself.The bowling club has been part of the social fabric of the village for  years, with the clubhouse and steps to the bowling green built in .The design and access statement also spells out what the bowling club means to the village and the potential consequencesthe proposals are not given the go ahead.ldquoIt is the only village sports club providing exercise and social, intergenerational contact through sport, and the only village team bowling leagues.ldquoThe expectation of visiting teams is now much higher than it used to be, and clubs such as North Berwick, Aberlady, Stenton and Gullane all have new improved facilities.ldquoThe title: queens-maundy-money-sent-church-elders-post
story: Alan Miller and Margaret Jeffrey had been due to travel to St Georgersquos Chapel, Windsor, to attend the Royal Maundy Thursday Service.The annual ceremony sees Queen Elizabeth II present symbolic money to people who have supported their church and community but the event was sadly cancelled due to the global pandemic.Instead, Alan and Margaret, who were both delighted to be given the honour, received the purses in the post.Both of the recipients, who live in East Linton, were shocked to receive letters last year inviting them to the event.Alan told the Courier he was overwhelmed when the letter came in the post and said: ldquoThe first thing I thought was lsquois this a scam rsquoldquoThe outside of the envelope said it was from Buckingham Palace and when you opened the letter it said Her Majesty invites you to be the recipient of the Maundy money.ldquoIt just seemed so wild and asit was not true but then Margaret got the same letter and I realised that it was right.ldquoIt just blew my head away.ldquoIrsquove seen the Queen handing out the Maundy money down the years and I never in my wildest dreams imagined that I would get it.Seventy-five-year-old Alan, an elder at the Parish of Traprain for more than  years, was due to travel to the service, which was to take place on April , with his we, Eleanor.At the service, each recipient would be given two purses, one red ndash containing a pound coinand a p piece representing the GB Olympic Team ndash and one white .Due to the coronavirus and travelling and gathering restrictions, both Alan and Margaret received their purses in the post.Margaret, originally an elder at Whittingehame Parish Church before it became part of the Parish of Traprain in , had planned to make the trip south with her daughter, Susan.The former housekeeper at Abbeyfield House in East Linton was ldquodisappointed not to be able to attend the event at Windsor but stressed these were exceptional circumstances.She said: ldquoIrsquom fortunate I was even thought about to go.ldquoI think we have got to get things right in le ndash the world is in a grave situation at the minute.Modest Margaret, , told the Courier she had seen people down the years receiving the award but added: ldquoIrsquove just lived an ordinary le ndash Irsquove not done anything special.Thank you for reading this story. title: resilient-musselburgh-team-moves-due-increased-demand

title: delivering-hope-cheer-supplies-couriers-community
story: Couriers are being delivered to  North Berwick residents who are unable to leave their homes due to coronavirus shielding thanks to a new support fund to help people in the town.While in Haddington, the townrsquos Rotary Club this week purchased  copies to deliver to residents in lockdown in their town.North Berwick Community Council chairman Judy Lockhart said the initiative was aimed, primarily, at residents who did not have access to the internet but wanted to find out what was happening in the area and to get vital information about how to get help and support.Copies of the paper are delivered by North Berwick Community Emergency Resilience Group volunteers to housing for older people, care homes, the day centre and people who were not able to get out of their homes.ldquoWe want to ensure that everyone knows whatrsquos going on and how to get help and support at a very dficult time, said Judy.ldquoThe Courier is a leline. We know local newsagents deliver to many people, but this short-term scheme will ensure that people who donrsquot get a delivery or who canrsquot afford a Courier are kept in touch. It is also important to support the Courier during this periodwe are to see it survive. Newspapers are essential for local democracy and the Courier regularly reports on issues we discuss at the council.One of the volunteers who deliver the newspaper is Susan Taylor ndash in her beloved Dolly CV which goes by the name of Myrtille.Susan, whose day job is working for the Church of Scotland as an executive assistant, is one of the team of resilience group volunteers picking up prescriptions for residents.ldquoI volunteered because I really feel for those people in our community who are at risk and isolated due to the Covid- outbreak, she said. ldquoI have met some lovely people so far and am glad I am in a position to help.The project is paid for through the townrsquos Community Emergency Resilience Fund ndash which comprises public donations, funding from North Berwick Community Council and the North Berwick Trust.Rotary Haddington was always looking for ways to support its community, said club president Malcolm Collins.ldquoOur idea to bulk-buy and distribute copies of the Courier to the elderly and vulnerable originated from one of our members who was quick to realise that a signicant number of such people would soon begin to feel isolated and lose touch with what was happening locallythey were unable to get out and buy a copy, he added.ldquoAs well as providing local news, the initiative shown by the Courier by including pages of extra puzzles in the paper was also thought to be useful to help keep folk entertained during these dficult times.ldquoWe have now taken this idea forward and arranged to bulk-buy copies of the Courier each week in advance, have them delivered to a central hub and then arranged for them to be distributed to other locations where they can be made available to those in need e.g. Our Community Kitchen, those in care homes and other locations as they become known to us.Rotary Haddington members would ensure that the papers were delivered where they were needed, he added.Courier Editor Robbie Scott said: ldquoWersquore so grateful to these groups for supporting our communities during lockdown and the amazing work they do inspires us to produce the best papers that we can.ldquoFor them to also directly support us at a dficult time for all businesses is incredible and we thank them immensely.Anyone wishing to buy copies of the Courier for delivery to communities should email title: yummikeys-aiming-spread-joy-sunflower-seeds
story: Elspeth Fawcett set up Yummikeys three years ago, an eco-friendly toy company that makes stainless steel sensory toys for babies.Elspeth has started adding sunflower seeds to all of her orders for people to plant inside or in their gardens.The -year-old mum of three is also donating five per cent of all profits directly to For the Love of Scrubs, an initiative set up to provide scrubs to frontline NHS staff during the coronavirus pandemic, and Womenrsquos Aid.Elspeth said: ldquoI really want to do something to help spread happiness and joy over the coming weeks as I appreciate that this is such a dficult time for everyone.ldquoIrsquove chosen to add sunflower seeds to all orders as this is something that everyone can enjoy, even those who are not fortunate enough to have gardens. I love seeing all of the rainbows in peoples windows but we can only enjoy these for the short time that we are out exercising each day, so my intention is for these sunflowers to be enjoyed for the rest of the time we are at home or in our gardens.On donating her profits she added: ldquoIrsquom a small business working hard to overcome the challenges that coronavirus has placed on all of our lives, but I feel this is really the right thing to do as my donation will hopefully help those who need it most right now.Thank you for reading this story. title: uk-lockdown-eased-schools-travel-sport
story: This will be a ldquomenu of options with the dates and times driven by the current state of the outbreak in the UK, he added.Ministers have faced continued questioning over the UKrsquos plan for lting its coronavirus lockdown, as European countries begin to ease their own restrictions.Italy and Spain are among those planning small steps to relax measures, while the Scottish and Welsh governments have set out dferent visions of how the current restrictions could be lted when the outbreak is under control.The next three-week review of the lockdown restrictions is due on Thursday, May .But how could the lockdown be lted across ious sectors  Heres a round-up of what you need to know.SchoolsUnder lockdown, schools and colleges have largely been closed, except for the children of essential workers, and it is thought this could be among the first restrictions to be eased.But Education Secretary Gavin Williamson previously said the Government had ldquono plans to open schools over the summer period, while Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab said it would be ldquoinconceivable without some further measures in place.Head teachers have previously been advised to start making preparations on how schools could safely reopen, with the Association of School and College Leaderssuggesting a staggeredof pupils.ConstructionSome of Britainrsquos largest housebuilders ndash including Persimmon, Taylor Wimpey and Redrow ndash have already announced plans to reopen building sites in late April or early May.Under Government guidance, construction has been permittedin accordance with social distancing rules, but many companies halted work in response to the crisis.The Home Builders Federation said the restart is expected to be gradual, being dependent on how far supporting suppliers and services, such as building inspectors, mortgage lenders and conveyancers, can alsoto work.Activity will also be limited until the Government changes advice which effectively prohibits all but exceptional house moves.OfficesProperty services provider CBRE has drawn from its experiences in Asia to issue guidance to workplaces on how offices might approach re-opening in the future.It advises against a ldquofull throttleto work, with social-distancing measures needing to be reduced gradually and in line with public health guidance.It suggests businesses should establish internal taskforces to consider issues around access to PPE supplies, touchless technologies, temperature screening and reconfiguring work environments.Social gatheringsLimited social gatherings could be permitted in an easing of lockdown, but should be accompanied by extensive testing and contact tracing, one expert has suggested.Dr Joshua Moon, research fellow in sustainability research methods in the Science Policy Research Unitat the University of Sussex Business School, said the Government could adopt a ldquoslow release valve approach to the issue.He explained a phased approach might see certain sections of the population, for example healthy middle-aged people, given more freedoms initially, but he warned this risked the most vulnerable suffering the hardships of lockdown the longest.Dr Moon said family ldquoclusters could gradually be permitted to socialise, but could not make long journeys to do so, while most businesses remained shut.ldquoThe idea is that within those groups you can quite easily test, trace and isolate, he said, adding that it was harder to monitor for people moving around in public.HospitalitySector representative body UKHospitality has focused its energies on getting business support extended to places like bars and restaurants.A spokesman suggested that evenvenues were allowed to open with reduced capacity, businesses would still struggle financially.The All Party Parliamentary Group for Hospitality and Tourism has launched an urgent inquiry into how the sectors could reopen.This includes looking at operational challenges, reactivating supply chains, Government support and encouraging demand. A report is expected by mid-May.Pub chain Wetherspoonrsquos has said it plans to reopen its bars and hotels in June and said that due to it having larger than average pubs social distancing measures could be applied.RetailMinisters are thought to be considering allowing some non-essential businesses to open, such as garden centres and car showrooms, provided social-distancing could be maintained.Lobby group the British Retail Consortium has produced guidelines on how stores could prepare for the easing of restrictions.The guidance draws on lessons learned from supermarkets in recent weeks to ensure the re-opening of non-essential firms can be done safely.Advice coverslimiting entry and exit points, using floor markings to outline social distancing and keeping changing rooms closed.The guidance also suggests installing cleaning stations with hand sanitiser and disinfectant wipes at the front of stores.SportIt is understood Culture Secretary Olive Dowden has been working on a plan for major sports to be played behind closed doors when some social-distancing rules are eased.Weekly meetings are to be held between the Government, Public Health England and medical officials from sports bodies, with the issue due to be on the table when ministers review current measures next month.Key questions that need to be tackled include testing requirements, burdens on emergency services and the possible impact on fan behaviour ndash such as impromptu gatherings outside grounds.Sporting bodies are understood to be keen to resume full training safely as soon as possible.TravelLast week, low-cost European carrier Wizz Air announced plans to resume some flights from Luton Airport on May .Cabin crew will be required to wear masks and gloves on all flights and will distribute sanitising wipes for passengers, while new distancing measures will also be introduced during boarding.Mr Raab has indicated that officials are looking at possible checks at air and sea ports, with passengers arriving in the UK required to quarantine for  days.Meanwhile, the Rail, Maritime and Transportunion warned there was ldquozero chance of ramping up transport services soon, amid speculation of an increase on May  or May  when a new rail timetable is due.Last week, industry sources said no dates have yet been agreed or announced.

title: community-resilience-can-turn-help
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at five of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port SetonTHE resilience effort in Cockenzie and Port Seton has been helping launch a Fair Share hub at the Port Seton Centre this past week.The charity Fair Share delivers surplus food from supermarkets to the centre every Friday.The hub will cover the whole of East Lothian and support the centrersquos existing work to provide hot meals and food packs to families in need and children who would usually receive free school meals.Bryan Hickman, chairman of the local community council, which is leading the resilience effort, said: ldquoWe are still delivering food to those who need it but the Fair Share hub has been set up.ldquoWe receive food like coffee, cereal, milk and biscuits but this could change every week.ldquoItrsquos really good news that we have set this up as it will help us give other types of food. It will also help us financially because it is free.Meanwhile, the resilience effort is continuing to help those in need when requests come in, and currently has about  volunteers.A volunteer has also started offering a dog walking service.Contact detailsThose who require assistance can call the resilience emergency number on  . Updates are also posted on the Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council Twitter twitter CandPSCC and Facebook pages www.facebook Cockenzie-and-Port-Seton-Community-Council-.East SaltounHumbie, East and West Saltoun and BoltonFOUR volunteer groups are operating to help residents of neighbouring rural villages during the coronavirus pandemic.A resilience group, involving members of the Humbie, East and West Saltoun and Bolton Community Council, was previously formed.Alastair Beck, community council treasurer, said: ldquoVolunteers in the four village groups are supporting residents in their communities.ldquoAnyone in need of support, whether for shopping, pharmacy runs, etc, or who would just like someone to talk to should make contact with their village coordinator.Contact detailsPeople in Bolton should contact Shena Jamieson on   or by email shenajamieson@aol.East Saltoun residents can contact Buffy Neilson on   or buffyneilson@yahoo.In West Saltoun, Derek Smith is the point of contact on   or by emailing coruisk@gmail.Finally, in Humbie, people are encouraged to call Margo Hodge on   or email humbiehelp@gmailMacmerryMacmerry and GladsmuirA LEAFLET drop to all residents across Macmerry and Gladsmuir last week led to the numbers of calls dealt with by the resilience team double.The team also offer a hot food service, and requests for this have quadrupled in the past week from two to eight.Stevie Sutherland, one of the resilience co-ordinators, said: ldquoI definitely envisage this increasing as it develops.ldquoSome might use it for a couple of days, some might use it for a couple of months.ldquoMaybe we can give a bit more help, askingthere is anything  they need.ldquoNeighbours are also looking after one another and they seem to be managing themselves.ldquoI think most people receiving meals are over .ldquoAll that happens is they are getting one hot meal per day. They might not be getting anything  but itrsquos just making sure they are getting at least one every day.Children have also been receiving wool in craft packs and are encouraged to make colourful pom poms, and hang them from their gates or a nearby lamppost.Stevie said: ldquoThe pom poms will start gathering pace now. Wersquove also put some posts up about it on social media. ldquoHopefully we are going to be inundated with them.ldquoWe want both villages to be decorated with as much colour as possible, in support of frontline workers.Volunteers at the resilience group are continuing to help with prescription and shopping collections.Stevie added: ldquoItrsquos just about getting that help out there.Contact detailsMore information is available on the resilience grouprsquos Facebook and Twitter pages, at facebook groups   and twitter MacmerryTeamMusselburghMusselburghAN AVERAGE of  lunch packs have been prepared and distributed weekly, as well as a daily distribution of emergency food packs by the growing army of  volunteers who make up the Resilient Musselburgh team.And about  free soup and sandwich lunches have been distributed to Whitecraig residents each week, Monday to Friday, by Graham Blaikie, who runs Mercat Grill, helped by Mrs Bennett.The team is also now providing freshly cooked meals.Community Councillor Margaret Stewart explained: ldquoHickory Foods, based at Eskmills, have offered us their kitchen facilities and staff for free to prepare freshly cooked meals which are delivered into the community.ldquoThe staff at the base identy, from referral forms, those who they feel would be most in need and make contact to offer this food support.ldquoWe are trialling this on a two-week basis, where a three-course freshly prepared meal is delivered to those identied for seven days a week.ldquoThis week  meals will have been delivered. This support is specically targeted at vulnerable members of the community, where it is felt that they would benefit from a nutritious meal. All meals are packaged and labelled with instructions for heating.ldquoThis will be reviewed after the first two weeks. However, we have been seeking feedback and, so far, it has been exceptional, with many comments of appreciation and thanks.She added: ldquoWe are still looking to build on our pool of volunteers to ensure sustainability, so anyone who would be interested in supporting us can register via eastlothian.gov.uk info  musselburgh_area_partner ship  resilient_musselburgh.As well as the pound, awarded to the Musselburgh Area Partnership to support the whole community response, Resilient Musselburgh has received a number of funding donations from community groups and organisations.Volunteers have been delivering information leaflets to households in targeted areas and Councillor Andy Forrest arranged for Musselburgh Post Office to deliver leaflets to all other locations.Contact detailsThe Resilient Musselburgh dedicated support number is  .PrestonpansPrestonpansDEMAND for assistance from the Prestonpans resilience team increased last week, reflecting both the pressure families are under going into week five of the lockdown, and a wider awareness of the support available to local people.Allan Sneddon, who is leading the Prestonpans resilience effort, said: ldquoOur volunteers have started providing a dog walking service for several people who are shielding, and this is being co-ordinated on our team leadersrsquo WhatsApp group. This seems to be working very well.ldquoThe three local Scotmid stores in Prestonpans are offering a free home delivery service and, with the help of our resilience volunteersrsquo leaflets advertising the service, have been delivering throughout the town. We are also helping to deliver shopping orders.The Pantry, operating from the Pennypit, also saw demand for meals increase in week four, with  meals delivered to households throughout the town.The Pantry is receiving lots of practical support in the form of food donations from local stores in the area, and financial donations have been given by the Prestonpans and Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Councils, PSG Area Partnership, Prestonpans British Legion, Prestonpans Labour Club and Longniddry Villa FC.Prestonpans Community Council have also set aside funds to help households who are struggling to make ends meet and the Corra Foundation, Scottish Governmentrsquos Food Fund, the Prestonpans British Legion and RBL Scotland Pipe Band have made signicant donations to this fund.Contact detailsIf anyone needs help, they should telephone   or email prestonpansresilience@gmailIF YOUR resilience group would like to purchase copies of the Courier to deliver to residents who are shielding and unable to leave their homes then please email Courier Editor Robbie Scott via rscott@eastlothiancourier for details. Copies can be delivered to a destination of your choice before being distributed by your volunteers.

title: community-resilience-can-turn-help-elphinstone-gifford-haddington-longniddry-tranent
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at five of the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Elphinstone. Picture: Google MapsElphinstoneDOG walking, collecting prescriptions, shopping and much more are on offer from generous volunteers in Elphinstone.A spokeswoman for the community highlighted a number of services were on offer to people during the coronavirus pandemic.She said: ldquoThis care has included help with dog walking, collecting prescriptions, shopping, daily delivery of meals and food, a friendly chat over the phone or at a distance from the garden gate.ldquoA number of community partners have rallied to ensure that everyone is cared for during this Covid- pandemic.ldquoThis has only been possible with the operational support of East Lothian Roots and Fruits, Elphinstone Community Association, Elphinstone Primary School, East Lothian Council, Councillor Colin McGinn, Pennypit Community Trust, East Lothian Foodbank, Home-Start East Lothian, Walk With Scott Foundation, Heavy Sound, Social Bite, Tesco, Fair Share, Hibernian Community Foundation and generous donations from McInroy  Wood [Haddington].ldquoThis important work has greatly strengthened relationships and working practices that will continue to grow and develop long after we overcome this devastating pandemic.ldquoCollectively, this network has shown incredible reach, capacity, experience and skills as they endeavour to meet the needs of everyone in need of support.Contact detailsAny residents of Elphinstone who would like to request support can contact the team through email ndash colinmcginn@hotmail ndash or  .Gford. lives we have one man who cooked for royalty and so many others with extraordinary tales to share.ldquoIt is a real privilege to get to know them.Contact detailsAnyone needing help can contact: Jo Allen, GCC chair, on   or ChairGfordCC@gmail Adam White, GCC vice chair, on   or adamjswhite@outlook Wendy Ferguson, GCC treasurer, on   or wendyferguson.wf@gmail Aniko Schuetz Bradwell, minister, on   or aschuetzbradwell@churchofscotland.org.ukHaddingtonHaddingtonAN INCREASING number of people are getting in touch with community resilience volunteers in Haddington.The townrsquos community council has been at the heart of setting up a squad of volunteers to help people during the coronavirus pandemic.Chris McEwan, vice-chairman of the community council, stressed they would do whatever they could to help those who needed assistance.He said: ldquoWe have managed in the past few weeks to get our contact details out there a lot better.ldquoPeople are phoning and contacting us, and our volunteers are basically now really getting themselves into a nice routine.ldquoThey have got quite a few people that they are looking after week on week.Services being offered through the resilience volunteers are also increasing.Collections of shopping and prescriptions have been available for a number of weeks.Now, a dog walking service and getting tradesmen out to solve issues in the home have also been introduced.Mr McEwan took the time to once again praise the efforts of the volunteers.He said: ldquoI must say, the town has really, really done well and I have to thank all my volunteers and the people I donrsquot know about who are helping as well.ldquoWe have had people who have had maintenance issues and we have managed to get some tradesmen out to them.ldquoTradesmen are offering to help, some doing it for revenue but a couple doing it for nothing people are helping for nothing.Mr McEwan also highlighted that there was a wide range of information on the grouprsquos website, with sections set up to alert people to community help and coronavirus.On top of that, there is a section for food deliveries, ranging from butchers and bakers to prepared meals and takeaways which are open in the town.The community council plans to keep the list as up to date as possible for people.Contact detailsAnyone looking to find out more can visit www.haddingtoncc.org.uk while anyone looking for assistance can e-mail resilienthcc@haddingtoncc.org.uk or call  .Longniddry. Picture: Google MapsLongniddryONE resident in Longniddry has started offering a free dog walking service for those unable to take their four-legged friend on its daily stroll.Those interested should contact Danni Anderson on Facebook.Meanwhile, the villagersquos resilience effort is still helping those in need and answering queries from residents.It is being led by the local church and supported by Longniddry Community Council.Sheila Jamieson told the Courier that people in the village have been helping family and neighbours on their own accord, so enquiries to her are still fairly low.However, she has still received some enquiries, such as people asking how they can get hearing aid batteries, food parcels and online food deliveries.She currently has  volunteers ready to help her deliver the resilience effort should the need arise.Sheila said: ldquoAs long as people are getting the help they need ndash we are still here and doing what we can.ldquoIrsquom overwhelmed and so grateful for the volunteers and the nice community.ldquoAll of the people in the community are coming together. We are coping at the moment and getting calls from the council with other people who might also need help.As with other resilience groups, it is helping with delivering prescriptions ndash but the local pharmacy offers a delivery service to those over the age of .Contact detailsThose who need any help or assistance can call Sheila Jamieson on  .Tranent. Picture: Google MapsTranentVOLUNTEERS covering Tranent and Elphinstone delivered leaflets to every house in the area, with help from Ross High Rugby Club, reminding people of the help they can receive from their local resilience group.The number of people signed up to volunteer in the area has now risen to , as the number of calls the group receives also continues to rise.The resilience effort in Tranent and Elphinstone is being led by the local community council and overseen by member Mike Falconer.People are continuing to help out with requests such as collecting shopping, picking up prescriptions, and walking dogs.The resilience group is also helping Fundamental Foods and the Pennypit Trust with food deliveries, as well as assisting with its school hub effort.Contact detailsUpdates are also posted on the resilience Facebook page, lsquoTranent Emergency Response ndash Coronavirusrsquo.Updates, information and advice are also shared on Radio Saltire as part of its community information feature.Anyone needing assistance can call   or email tranentemergencyresponse@gmailIF YOUR resilience group would like to purchase copies of the Courier to deliver to residents who are shielding and unable to leave their homes then please email Courier Editor Robbie Scott via rscott@eastlothiancourier for details.
